posts.title: Vegan Rhubarb and Ginger Loaf Cake
posts.title_plain: Vegan Rhubarb and Ginger Loaf Cake
posts.content: There’s such a small window in the year when we can enjoy rhubarb. When it appears, make the most of it! This rhubarb ginger loaf cake is the perfect place to start – the flavours go so well together, it’s a simple recipe and one you’ll go back to again and again. And as with most things rhubarb, serve with custard!

ingredients:
1½ cups self-raising flour
½ cup caster sugar or extra-fine granulated sugar
1½ tsp baking powder
½ tsp bicarbonate of soda
¼ tsp salt
1 tsp ground ginger
1 tbsp vinegar
½ cup oil (canola or sunflower work best)
¾ cup almond milk (dairy is fine if you're not vegan)
3 tbsp maple syrup
1 cup diced rhubarb + 1 stalk sliced lengthways 
2 tbsp stem ginger syrup/ginger jam/strawberry jam
method:
1. Preheat your oven to 350F or 180 Celsius.
  2. Line a loaf tin with parchment paper and set aside.
  3. In a large mixing bowl, measure out the dry ingredients and whisk to combine.
  4. To the mixing bowl, add the vinegar, oil, almond milk and maple syrup. Stir until you have a smooth cake batter. If the batter is too loose, add more almond milk 1 tbsp at a time.
  5. Fold in the sliced rhubarb.
  6. Transfer the mixture to the loaf tin.
  7. Top the mixture with the long slices of rhubarb.
  8. Brush them with the syrup or jam.
  9. Bake for 35 minutes, or until the top of the cake bounces back when gently pressed. You can also insert a skewer into the cake - if it comes out clean, it's cooked.
  10. Allow the cake to cool for 10 minutes before attempting to remove from the tin.
  11. Serve warm with custard.

posts.title: Vegan Almond Meal Cookies (Ekadashi)
posts.content:
Sometimes you need a chocolate chip cookie and you need it to not fill you with immediate regret. If you can relate, you came to the right place. These cookies are soft and chewy and studded with bittersweet chocolate. The coconut sings through from the coconut oil, sugar and shredded coconut so ‘you’re welcome’ coconut fans.

These aren’t exactly low in fat but they’re free of refined sugar if you use coconut sugar like I did, and they’re gluten-free and ekadashi-friendly (do I need to provide any more reasons to bake these? Didn’t think so.

 

Thanks to Minimalist Baker for the inspiration for these.

Happy baking! Xx

ingredients:
1¼ cup almond meal
¼ cup bittersweet chocolate, chopped
½ cup shredded unsweetened coconut 
¼ tsp salt
½ tsp baking powder
¼ cup soft brown sugar (I used coconut sugar)
3 tbsp liquid coconut oil 
¼ tsp vanilla bean paste
¼ cup thoroughly mashed ripe banana
method:
1. In a mixing bowl, measure out all the dry ingredients and stir through.
  2. Whisk together the coconut oil, vanilla and mashed banana and add to the mixing bowl.
  3. Fold the ingredients until combined.
  4. Chill the dough in the refrigerator for at least 30 minutes.
  5. When you're ready to bake, preheat your oven to 375F or 190C.
  6. Using a cookie scoop (or tablespoon if you don't have one), shape your cookie dough into 1 inch balls.
  7. Place them on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper, spacing 2 inches apart. Press them down slightly into rounds.
  8. Sprinkle with sea salt or pink Himalayan salt.
  9. Bake the cookies for 10-12 minutes until golden brown at the edges.
  10. Let them cool on the baking sheet before moving them - they will be quite delicate.

posts.title: Blackberry and Apple Crumble
posts.content:
Crumbles are easily one of the easiest desserts you can make. Flour, butter, sugar, fruit. Purists would argue that’s all you need; I prefer to add oats and nuts to crumbles for more texture.

Most fruits work well in a crumble – pears, plums, peaches, rhubarb, blueberries etc. So if you don’t fancy apple and blackberry (don’t knock it ’til you’ve tried it), feel free to mix it up.

Apples and blackberries are somewhat autumnal but the minute I saw them at the farmer’s market this week, I knew I was going to be making this dish. I suggest you do the same.

ingredients:
2 large apples (Bramley and Granny Smith are great for crumbles), peeled, cored and cubed
1 cup blackberries 
1 tbsp lemon juice
3 tbsp sugar 
1 tsp cinnamon


For the crumble topping: 
1 cup all purpose flour (125g)
2 tbsp soft brown sugar (I used coconut sugar) 
5 tbsp oats (50g)
Pinch of salt
½ cup (100g) cold butter, cubed 
¼ (50g) cup mixed chopped nuts
method:
1. Preheat the oven to 200˚C or 400F.
  2. Toss the cubed apple with the sugar, lemon juice and cinnamon. Stir through the blackberries, then scatter in an ovenproof dish.
  3. For the crumble topping, mix the flour, oats, sugar and a pinch of salt in a separate bowl.
  4. Using your fingers, rub in the cubed butter until the mixture resembles breadcrumbs. If there are some bigger chunks, that's fine. Stir through the chopped nuts.
  5. Ensure the fruit in the ovenproof dish is distributed evenly so that the crumble topping follows suit. Scatter the crumble on top of the fruit. Don't press it down.
  6. Bake the crumble until golden and bubbling - approximately 35-40 minutes.

posts.title: Vegan Mushroom Tikka
posts.content:
This mushroom tikka makes a great side dish or even a starter/appetizer. I made it to accompany tadka dal and paratha and it was pretty perfect.

I very slightly adapted it from Veg Recipes of India. This is so uncomplicated – just one mixing bowl and then throw it under the grill. Enjoy! If you recreate it let me know on Instagram!

ingredients:
Serves 2

12 button mushrooms, wiped clean with a damp paper towel
1 tbsp of fresh ginger, minced
1 tsp fresh green chilli, minced
½ tsp cayenne pepper
½ tsp paprika
1 tsp ajwain seeds
1 pinch turmeric powder
2 tbsp oil
2-3 tbsp chickpea/garbanzo/gram flour 
salt to taste
freshly cracked black pepper 
juice of half a lemon
coriander leaves to garnish

skewers for grilling (optional)
method:
1. Slice off the top layer of each mushroom stalk and ensure all the mushrooms have been wiped well. (If you wash mushrooms they will become extremely soggy and release tons of moisture when cooked - bleurgh)
  2. In a mixing bowl, and add all the ingredients except the flour and coriander leaves. Stir well to combine.
  3. Cover the bowl and set aside to marinade for at least 30 minutes.
  4. If you plan to skewer the mushrooms, soak your skewers in cold water (to prevent burning under the grill)
  5. When you're ready to cook the mushrooms, preheat your grill/broiler.
  6. Add the flour to the marinaded mushrooms and stir to coat each mushroom evenly in the batter.
  7. Skewer the mushrooms if you wish. If not, simply lay some foil out on a baking tray and drizzle some oil onto it. Place the mushrooms on the sheet and drizzle lightly with oil.
  8. Grill/broil the mushrooms for 12-15 minutes, flipping half way through. Keep an eye on them to prevent burning.
  9. Once cooked, garnish with fresh coriander and serve hot with fresh lime or lemon wedges.

posts.title: Vegan ‘Butter Chicken’
posts.content:
Ok, so it doesn’t contain butter or chicken, but there’s no other name for it (is there?) I actually used a combination of tofu and vegan chicken strips from Beyond Meat. I highly recommend both options – it really depends on what you might prefer/what you can get a hold of.

There are a few steps involved with this recipe but it comes together pretty quickly. As long as you get your tofu draining and your cashews soaking in good time, it won’t take long at all.

Feel free to adjust the spicing according to your personal taste – more green chilli, less cardamom etc. I didn’t actually use garam masala because it doesn’t agree with me but I feel like it would be rude not to include it, so there it is. I had some very (beginning-to-wrinkle) ripe grape tomatoes in the fridge and used those instead of crushed tomatoes. Basically, do what you want – fresh, canned, it’s all good and the results are all yum.

The curry is very flavourful and creamy without using cream or coconut milk (both lovely, but high in saturated fats). In order to keep this dish lean and high in just protein, I decided to use cashews for creaminess and they’re very effective. If you’d rather use cream or coconut milk, I’m sure it’ll be just as delicious!

I hope you enjoy this dish as much as we did – please do share your recreations with me! And in case you need a good naan recipe, here you go

ingredients:
Serves 4:

2 12oz blocks extra-firm tofu 
1 red bell pepper
1 cup shredded cabbage
½ cup cashews, soaked in water for at least 1 hour, and then drained
2-3 tbsp oil 
1 tsp cumin seeds 
3 cardamom pods
5-6 peppercorns
½ tsp ground cinnamon
2 tbsp fresh grated ginger
1 tbsp fresh minced green chilli
1 tsp garam masala (optional)
1 cup crushed tomatoes
salt, to taste
fresh coriander/cilantro to garnish
method:
1. Drain your tofu. You could cut it into blocks but i broke it up with my hands to create chunks. Let the chunks drain for at least 30 minutes in a sieve to get rid of as much moisture as possible.
  2. Remove the stalk of the bell pepper and slice in half. Lay the two halves (skin side up on a baking tray lined with foil. Broil/grill the pepper until the skin has blackened.
  3. Once blackened, remove from the broiler/grill and fold the foil around the bell pepper to seal it and set aside for 2 minutes. Discard the skins from the bell pepper and set the pepper to one side.
  4. Line the baking tray with baking parchment.
  5. Gently press the chunks to remove any excess moisture. Place the tofu chunks on the tray in one layer, season with salt, and place under the broiler for 5-10 minutes until lightly browned. Flip the chunks over and broil again until the other side is lightly browned. Remove from the broiler/grill and set the tofu to one side.
  6. Now you can start on your curry sauce.
  7. In a pestle and mortar, grind together the cumin seeds, peppercorns and the black seeds from inside the cardamom pods.
  8. In a large non-stick pan over a medium heat, add the oil.
  9. Let the oil heat up and then add the ground spices, followed by the ginger, chilli and cabbage. Season the cabbage with salt.
  10. Stir frequently to ensure the mixture doesn't stick to the pan. It will become very fragrant as the cabbage softens and becomes translucent.
  11. To create a smooth sauce, add the softened spiced cabbage to a blender, along with the drained cashews, bell pepper halves and crushed tomatoes. Pulse the ingredients until you have a smooth curry base.
  12. Return the curry base to the non-stick pan along with the tofu chunks. Taste and add salt if needed. Garnish with coriander/cilantro and serve hot with rice or roti (or both!)

posts.title: Vegan Rice Krispie Treats
posts.content:
Rice Krispie treats were a favourite of mine as a child. Vegan marshmallows were elusive for so long (or perhaps I didn’t search hard enough) – either way, as soon as I found them, these were first on the list. They’re are fun, easy to make and super quick to put together.

I also add sea salt and very bitter dark chocolate to contrast the sweetness. Totally optional, but highly recommended!

ingredients:
2 tbsp Earth Balance or other plant-based butter
2 cups vegan marshmallows (I highly recommend Dandies)
4 cups vegan rice krispie cereal 

sea salt (optional)
50g melted dark chocolate (optional)
method:
1. In small non-stick saucepan, melt the vegan butter over a low heat. Add the marshmallows and stir until completely melted. Remove from heat.
  2. In a large mixing bowl, measure out the rice krispies.
  3. Using a spatula to scrape out as much as possible, pour the melted mixture into the mixing bowl. If you are using sea salt, you can a pinch now. Stir until all the cereal is well coated.
  4. Transfer the mixture into a 9x9inch pan. Press the mixture down and ensure it is evenly distributed.
  5. If using, melt the dark chocolate in a small bowl in 30 second increments in the microwave.
  6. Drizzle the melted chocolate over the rice krispies.
  7. Once the mixture has cooled, cut the treats into 2in squares.

posts.title: Vegan Dirty Chai Cupcakes
posts.content: I discovered the magic of ‘dirty chai’ in San Francisco recently – I had a ‘dirty horchata’ bubble tea and it was pretty much life-changing: spiced chai and a shot of espresso. Why choose between chai and coffee when you can have the best of both?
posts.excerpt: I discovered the magic of ‘dirty chai’ in San Francisco recently – I had a ‘dirty horchata’ bubble tea and it was pretty much life-changing: spiced chai and a shot of espresso. Why choose between chai and coffee when you can have the best of both?

categories.title: Recipe
categories.description: This is where you add new recipes to the site.

attachments.title: Processed with VSCO with f2 preset
attachments.caption: Processed with VSCO with f2 preset

ingredients:
12 cupcakes 

For the chai cupcakes:
1½ cups self-raising flour
½ cup vegan caster sugar or extra-fine granulated sugar
1½ tsp baking powder
½ tsp bicarbonate of soda
¼ tsp salt
½ tsp ground cinnamon
½ tsp ground ginger
½ tsp ground nutmeg
2 tbsp maple syrup
2 tbsp Earth Balance cinnamon spread, melted (optional)
1 tbsp vinegar
½ cup oil (canola or sunflower work best)
¾ cup almond milk

For the espresso frosting:
1/2 cup vegan butter (I used one stick of Earth Balance vegan buttery sticks)
2 ½ - 3 cups powdered sugar 
3-4 tbsp espresso
method:
1. Preheat your oven to 180C or 350F.
  2. Remove the vegan butter from the refrigerator to allow it to soften.
  3. Line a cupcake pan with paper cases.
  4. In a mixing bowl, sift the dry ingredients (including the spices)
  5. Melt the cinnamon spread if using it.
  6. Add the maple syrup and cinnamon spread to the dry ingredients.
  7. Add the vinegar directly onto the baking powder and soda. The ingredients will react and you’ll see lots of bubbles. This is exactly what you’re looking for.
  8. In quick succession, add the almond milk and oil.
  9. Mix the ingredients together until smooth. Beat for a further two minutes.
  10. Spoon the mixture into the cases, distributing it evenly.
  11. Bake the cupcakes for approximately 16 minutes. When the top of a cupcake is pressed gently, it should bounce back up. If it doesn’t, bake for a further 2 minutes, until it does bounce back.
  12. Let the cupcakes cool in the pan for 5 minutes before transferring to a wire rack.
  13. Make an espresso (or strong coffee) and set aside to cool.
  14. While the cupcakes and coffee cools, prepare the frosting.
  15. To a mixing bowl, add the softened vegan butter and beat until smooth.
  16. Gradually add the powdered sugar and espresso - ½ cup of sugar and 1 tbsp of espresso at a time, until you have a smooth buttercream texture
  17. Frost your cupcakes.
  18. Top with more cinnamon powder and/or espresso powder.
  19. Devour!

posts.title: Vegan Poached Pear and Chocolate Cake
posts.title_plain: Vegan Poached Pear and Chocolate Cake
posts.content: I’ve always thought that pear with chocolate is an underrated combination. This cake brings them both together in the most delicious way. Soft, spiced pears enveloped in a dark chocolatey sponge cake. So good. And vegan if you use dairy-free milk & vegan sugars.
posts.excerpt: I’ve always thought that pear with chocolate is an underrated combination. This cake brings them both together in the most delicious way. Soft, spiced pears enveloped in a dark chocolatey sponge cake. So good. And vegan if you use dairy-free milk & vegan sugars.

ingredients:
2 pears (Boscs works very well for poaching) - peeled and the base trimmed to allow them to stand upright
½ cup sugar
2 cinnamon sticks
4 cloves
6 cardamom pods

1½ cups self-raising flour
½ cup caster sugar or extra-fine granulated sugar
¼ cup cocoa
1½ tsp baking powder
½ tsp bicarbonate of soda
¼ tsp salt
1 tbsp vinegar 
½ cup oil (canola or sunflower work best)
¾ cup warm milk (dairy or plant-based)
3 tbsp golden syrup or maple syrup
method:
1. Begin by poaching the pears: place the pears in a saucepan and cover with water.
  2. Add the sugar and spices and bring to a boil. Once boiling, turn the heat down and let the pears simmer for 25 minutes. Remove them from the liquid, and let them cool.
  3. Preheat your oven to 180 degrees Celsius or 350 Fahrenheit.
  4. Line a loaf tin with baking parchment
  5. In a mixing bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, cocoa, baking powder, baking soda and salt.
  6. Add the vinegar and swiftly follow with the warm milk, golden syrup and oil.
  7. Mix well until you have a smooth chocolatey cake batter.
  8. Place the poached pears in the loaf tin. Follow with the cake mixture.
  9. Bake the loaf for approximately 30 minutes, until the top has cracked slightly and bounces back if gently pressed. (A skewer test in this situation isn't wise because the pears are at the very centre of the cake)
  10. Allow the cake to cool in its tin before removing. Dust with icing (powdered) sugar before serving.

posts.title: Upside Down Blood Orange and Almond Cake
posts.title_plain: Upside Down Blood Orange and Almond Cake
posts.content:
This cake is so spectacular – it looks beautiful and tastes even better. Blood oranges can generally only be found at this time of year so if you spot them, grab them and make this cake! You will not regret it.

This recipe was adapted from a New York Times recipe – I decided to add almond meal and extract for a little something extra in terms of flavour and texture. Enjoy!

ingredients:
For the upside down magic:
3 small blood oranges (or 2 medium blood oranges)
3 tbsp butter
1/3 cup light brown sugar 
2 tsp fresh lemon juice

For the cake:
1 ¼ cup all purpose flour
½ cup almond meal
½ cup extra-fine granulated sugar or caster sugar
2 tsp baking powder
½ tsp baking soda
¼ tsp salt
1 tsp almond extract
The zest of 2 blood oranges
3 tbsp golden syrup (you can substitute honey if you wish)
1 tbsp vinegar
1 cup buttermilk
¼ cup tepid water
½ cup canola or sunflower oil
method:
1. Preheat your oven to 180 degrees celsius or 350 degrees Fahrenheit.
  2. Line an 8 inch cake tin with baking parchment.
  3. Using a very fine grater, remove the zest from your blood oranges and set it aside - you'll need about 2 tsp of zest.
  4. Slice the tops and bottoms off the oranges. Lay them on a flat surface and gently slice away the skin around the oranges.
  5. Slice rounds of around ¼ inch in thickness - you'll have approximately 10 slices of orange.
  6. In a small sauce pan, melt the brown sugar and butter. Add the lemon juice and let it warm for approximately 3 minutes.
  7. Transfer the brown sugar mixture to the bottom of the cake pan and spread it out as evenly as possible.
  8. Cover the brown sugar mixture with the slices of orange in one single even layer.
  9. To make the cake, sieve the flour into a large mixing bowl. Follow with the almond meal, sugar, baking powder, baking soda and salt. Whisk the dry ingredients together.
  10. Add the liquid ingredients and stir until you have a smooth cake batter.
  11. Pour the cake mix over the blood oranges.
  12. Gently tap the cake tin onto your kitchen counter to remove any air bubbles (this will allow an even rise)
  13. Bake the cake for approximately 35 minutes - until the top is golden brown, perhaps slightly cracked and if gently pressed, the top bounces back.
  14. Let the cake cool in the tin for ten minutes.
  15. Run a knife around the edge of the cake to ease removal.
  16. Place a plate upside down on top of the cake tin. Gripping the tin and plate together, flip over to allow the cake to sit on the plate. Remove the cake tin to reveal your 'upside down' blood orange and almond masterpiece.
  17. The times recommended cooling the cake totally before serving - I ate it warm, pretty much as soon as I turned it out - no complaints from me.

posts.title: Butternut Squash Stuffed Shells
posts.content:
I made this dish for the first time a week ago. I had absolutely no idea what to make for dinner and the only fresh produce I had in the fridge was butternut squash and parsley. Thanks to some rosemary and sage growing on our porch, the dish was off to a good start. It came together quite quickly because the method allows for multitasking.

You could also make this dish ahead of time and bake it right before serving.

ingredients:
Serves 2:

12 jumbo pasta shells
12oz butternut squash, cubed
1 sprig rosemary, washed and torn
Olive oil for roasting
Sea salt and cracked black pepper
2 tbsp butter
2 tbsp all purpose flour
1 ½ cup milk
½ cup grated sharp cheddar cheese, plus more for sprinkling
2-3 tbsp grated Parmesan
Handful of Italian parsley
method:
1. Preheat your oven to 375 degrees Fahrenheit or 190 degrees celsius.
  2. Add the cubed butternut squash to a baking tray and season with salt and pepper. Sprinkle the rosemary over the squash and drizzle with olive oil. Roast the squash for approximately 20 minutes until tender.
  3. While the squash is roasting, prepare the pasta: in a pan of boiling salted water, cook the shells for 8 minutes and then drain.
  4. Transfer the roasted squash to a food processor and pulse until the mixture is smooth. Taste and add more salt and pepper if necessary.
  5. Stuff each shell with the squash mixture and lay them out in your baking dish. I used an 8" square dish.
  6. For the parsley cream sauce, heat a non stick sauce pan over a medium heat.
  7. Add the butter and the flour to the pan and cook for 2 minutes, stirring frequently.
  8. Add the milk to the pan and stir continuously until it starts to thicken and simmer.
  9. Once thickened, add the Parmesan and ½ cup of grated cheddar. Stir until you have a smooth and creamy sauce.
  10. Finely chop the parsley or pulse it in your food processor and it to the cream sauce.
  11. Pour the parsley cream over the shells, and then sprinkle more grated cheddar on top.
  12. In a shallow pan over a low heat, melt a nob of salted butter. Add the sage leaves and flash fry in the bubbling butter. They will cook very quickly so take them out the minute they're coated in butter and bubbling.
  13. Bake the whole dish for approximately 20 minutes until it is bubbling and golden brown on top.

posts.title: Coconut Citrus Cake
posts.content: I used lemon to flavour this coconut cake, but lime and coconut also work really well. Despite lots of shredded coconut, this cake remains light and fluffy thanks to the buttermilk. Unlike with most egg-free sponge recipes, using buttermilk keeps the sponge pale – I find that using regular milk browns the top of the cake too much.

ingredients:
Cake: 
1 ½ cups all purpose flour
½ cup cane sugar
1 ½ tsp baking powder
½ tsp baking soda 
¼ tsp salt 
1 tbsp vinegar
½ cup shredded coconut
½ cup sunflower oil 
1 cup buttermilk 
¼ cup water
3 tbsp golden syrup or maple syrup
zest of one lemon or lime

Citrus frosting: 

2oz unsalted butter, at room temperature
2oz powdered (icing) sugar 
6oz cream cheese, at room temperature (this is crucial)
2 tbsp freshly squeezed lime juice or lemon juice
method:
1. Preheat your oven to 180C or 350F.
  2. Line a 9 inch cake tin with parchment paper.
  3. Sift the flour into a mixing bowl.
  4. Add the remaining dry ingredients.
  5. Add the shredded coconut, then follow with the liquids. Whisk together until you have a smooth cake batter. Add the zest of your lemon or lime.
  6. Pour the cake batter into your lined tin and bake for 27-30 minutes until golden. The top of the cake should bounce back if gently pressed and a skewer inserted into the centre of the cake should come out clean.
  7. Allow the cake to cool completely.
  8. When the cake is totally cool and ready to frost, be sure that your butter and cream cheese are at the same (room) temperature - if not, you might get lumps of cream cheese in the icing. Both cream cheese and butter will give in the same way when pressed gently if they're ready.
  9. Cream the powdered sugar and butter together until pale. With a hand whisk or whisk attachment in a stand mixer, this should take 2-3 minutes.  Add the cream cheese in, in thirds, allowing each bit to incorporate before adding the next.
  10. Add the citrus juice and whisk until the the mixture is smooth.
  11. Frost the cake as desired.
  12. Top with toasted coconut flakes.

posts.title: Pumpkin Spice Scones
posts.content:
I hadn’t even heard of pumpkin scones until I moved to the USA. Last week (or was it the week before?), when Starbucks launched its ‘PSL’ (Pumpkin Spice Latte) and a host of autumnal treats, my friends were so excited.

I was envious. I had to know why pumpkin scones merit that level of joy. So obviously I made some. And now, friends, I understand the hype.

If you make these, you will too.

ingredients:
Makes 6 large scones or 9 medium

1 ½ cups self-raising flour (if you only have all purpose flour, use that and add a tsp of baking powder)

3 ½ tbsp (50g) cold butter, cubed

¼ tsp salt

¼ cup buttermilk

¼ cup pumpkin puree 

4 tbsp sugar

1 tsp ground cinnamon

½ tsp ground ginger

½ tsp ground nutmeg

3-4 tbsp buttermilk, to glaze

For the sweet glaze:

¼ cup powdered sugar

1 tsp milk

A sprinkle of ground cinnamon (optional)
method:
1. Preheat your oven to 400F or 200C.
  2. Line a large baking tray with parchment.
  3. In a food processor, pulse together the flour, salt and butter. It will quickly resemble breadcrumbs. Transfer mixture to a large mixing bowl.
  4. Add the sugar and spices and stir to combine.
  5. Create a well in the mixture and pour in the pumpkin puree and buttermilk.
  6. Bring mixture together with a fork. Once it is close to a dough, use your hands to work it gently into a smooth ball.
  7. Place the dough ball on a lightly floured surface. Sprinkle the top of the ball with a little flour and then roll out to a circle that is 3/4"-1 inch thick.
  8. Use a pizza cutter to divide the dough like you would a pizza: either 6 or 9 triangles.
  9. Transfer the scones to the baking tray, spacing 2 inches apart.
  10. Brush each scone with the buttermilk, then bake for 15-17 minutes until puffy and decidedly golden underneath.
  11. Once the scones have cooled totally, you can glaze them.
  12. Simply combine the sugar and milk (and cinnamon if using). It might not seem like that much milk will suffice but stir for at least a minute and you should have a drizzle-able glaze. If you don't, add a drop more milk.
  13. Drizzle a spoonful across each scone.
  14. Best enjoyed warm with coffee.

posts.title: Vegan Sticky Sesame Tofu
posts.content:
This tofu is the perfect accompaniment to stir fried rice or noodles. Sticky, sweet and slightly sour, you’ll be making it again and again.

The secret to crispy tofu is cubing it well in advance – it has to dry out as much as possible before you cook it or it’ll just be a bit squidgy and unpleasant. I also believe that drier tofu soaks up more flavour so you don’t feel the need to keep dousing it in seasoning.

I hope you’ll love this recipe as much as I do.

ingredients:
1 block of tofu
oil for greasing tray
1 tbsp sesame oil
3 tbsp golden syrup or honey (for non-vegans)
2 tbsp soy sauce
1 tbsp apple cider vinegar
2 tsp sesame seeds
1 tsp red chilli flakes
method:
1. A minimum of 2 hours before you want to cook the tofu, cube the block of tofu into half inch cubes and set aside to drain in a large sieve.
  2. Preheat your grill/broiler.
  3. On a greased baking tray, lay out the tofu and place under the grill for approximately 7 minutes or until golden.
  4. Remove the tray, toss the tofu to expose another side and grill for a further 7 minutes.
  5. Heat a non-stick pan over a medium heat, and add the tofu along with a tbsp of sesame oil.
  6. Add the soy sauce, vinegar and syrup. Stir gently to stop the mixture sticking to the bottom. It should be bubbling gently.
  7. Add the sesame seeds and chilli and cook for another minute.
  8. Taste the tofu and adjust seasonings as you see fit - you may prefer it spicier or sweeter.
  9. Devour.

posts.title: Vegan Stuffed Shells
posts.content:
Using cauliflower and cashews, this recipe produces a very convincing vegan ricotta. Paired with spinach and marinara, you really can’t go wrong.

This dish can be made in advance and baked just before serving. Enjoy!

ingredients:
Serves 2

12 jumbo pasta shells

For the marinara:
1 red pepper
1 can crushed tomatoes
1 handful fresh rosemary leaves
salt and pepper to taste

For the vegan ricotta:
½ cup cashews, soaked for 3 hours
1 cup cauliflower 'rice' (approx 5-6 florets,  pulsed in a food processor)
1/2 tsp nutritional yeast
1 tsp salt
juice of half a lemon 
1/2 cup wilted spinach
method:
1. Preheat your broiler/grill.
  2. Wash, halve and deseed the red pepper.
  3. Place the halves on a foil-lined baking tray and grill under broiler/grill until the skin is blackened on 50% of it.
  4. Remove the tray from the broiler/grill and seal up the foil around the peppers. Leave for 5 minutes.
  5. Open the foil parcel and peel off the red pepper skins.
  6. Blend the roasted pepper with the can of crushed tomatoes. Season with salt, pepper and chilli flakes to taste. Add the rosemary and simmer on a low heat for 10 minutes.
  7. Cook the jumbo shells in boiling water for 8-9 minutes.
  8. While the marinara simmers, you can begin making the ricotta. Pulse the soaked cashews in a food processor until they resemble ricotta.
  9. Transfer the cashews to a bowl and add the cauliflower rice, lemon juice, nutritional yeast, salt and spinach.
  10. Preheat your oven to 350F or 180 degrees Celsius.
  11. Slather some marinara at the bottom of the baking dish you're using.
  12. Once your pasta shells have drained and cooled, stuff each shell with the 'ricotta' and place in the baking dish.
  13. Drizzle more marinara atop the shells.
  14. Bake in the oven for 25 minutes.

posts.title: Herbed Naan Bread
posts.content: Homemade naan really is so much tastier than store-bought. Conventional ‘coriander naan’ recipes will use the herb as a garnish. I use it in the dough itself. It adds great depth of flavour and is more practical – garnishes fall off. This recipe is really simple – you just need to allow yourself enough time for the dough to rise. It’s worth the wait though – the naan will be super soft and fluffy, slightly crisp at the edges and the perfect way to mop up a good curry!

ingredients:
1 ½  tsp active dry yeast
2 tbsp warm water
1 tsp sugar

½ cup warm water
1tsp salt
1 ½ cups all purpose flour
5 tbsp yogurt
2 tbsp melted ghee or butter
3-4 tbsp freshly chopped coriander (cilantro)
2 tsp nigella/black cumin seeds
method:
1. In a bowl, stir the yeast, sugar and 2 tbsp of warm water. Ensure the yeast is stirred well into the water. Leave it to one side for 10 minutes, until it is frothy.
  2. In a large mixing bowl, combine the flour and salt.
  3. Add the yogurt to the frothy mixture.
  4. Create a well in the flour, then pour in the yogurt/yeast mixture, followed by the ghee, coriander and seeds.
  5. Use your finger tips to bring the dough ingredients together.
  6. Little by little, add the water until you have a soft sticky dough.
  7. Transfer the mixture to a lightly floured surface and knead for 5 minutes. The dough should be smooth and really soft. If you feel it's too sticky, you can add a spoon of flour.
  8. Lightly grease a large mixing bowl that will accommodate double the size of the dough.
  9. Roll the dough around in the ball until it's lightly coated in the oil.
  10. Cover the bowl with a damp cloth or cling film, then place it in an unlit oven or another draught-free place for 1.5 hours until the dough has doubled in size.
  11. Return the dough to a lightly floured surface and knead gently to remove the air pockets. Divide the dough (I use a pizza cutter) into 8 balls.
  12. Heat a non-stick frying pan over a high heat.
  13. Roll out the balls into 5 inch discs. Then using your hands, stretch the first disc out to a tear drop shape, before placing onto the hot pan. When bubbles form, flip it over. Cook until the underside has brown patches. Flip and cook for a further 30 seconds. Remove from the pan and brush with butter. Repeat for remaining dough balls.
  14. Serve warm.

posts.title: Cauliflower Buffalo ‘Wings’
posts.content: These ‘wings’ are flavourful, wholesome and addictive. They make for a great appetiser or snack and most of these ingredients will already be in your pantry. For those who are sworn enemies of cauliflower, I challenge you to try them – after 50 minutes in a very hot oven, you can hardly tell it’s cauliflower at all.

For those who are sworn enemies of cauliflower, I challenge you to try them – after 50 minutes in a very hot oven, you can hardly tell it’s cauliflower … Continue reading Cauliflower Buffalo ‘Wings’

ingredients:
1 head of cauliflower

1/2 cup unsweetened almond milk (for non-vegans, dairy milk and buttermilk work too) 

1/4 cup water

1/2 cup all-purpose flour

1/4 cup chickpea flour (gram flour)

1 tsp cumin seeds, toasted and ground

1 tsp of paprika

1/4 tsp sea salt

1/4 tsp cracked black pepper


For the buffalo coating:

2 tbsp vegan butter (or dairy butter)

1/2 - 3/4 cup hot sauce (depending on how spicy you would like it to be)
 
1 tsp brown sugar

1 tsp soy sauce or liquid aminos
method:
1. Preheat your oven to 425F or 220 degrees Celsius.
  2. Line a large baking tray with parchment paper (cooking spray won't work, it has to be parchment paper or a silpat mat)
  3. Wash the cauliflower and cut into medium sized florets.
  4. In a large mixing bowl, whisk together the flours, water and milk.
  5. Season the batter with the salt, pepper, toasted cumin and paprika.
  6. One by one, dip each floret into the batter, let the excess batter drip back into the bowl, and place on baking sheet.
  7. Get rid of excess batter and then keep the bowl aside for the coating.
  8. Once all your cauliflower has been battered, bake for 12 minutes, flip them, then bake for 12 more.
  9. While the cauliflower bakes, prepare the buffalo coating. Melt the butter in a small saucepan over a low heat and the hot sauce, soy sauce and sugar.
  10. Once it begins to simmer, take it off the heat. Pour the mixture into the mixing bowl you kept aside.
  11. Add the baked cauliflower to the mixing bowl and toss to coat evenly.
  12. Once coated, transfer the florets back to the baking sheet and bake for a further 25 minutes, flipping them half way through.
  13. Serve the 'wings' warm with mayonnaise or ranch dip.

posts.title: Blueberry Swirl Cheesecake
posts.content:
This cheesecake is a little fussy. It’s not a 5 ingredient-one bowl-throw it all in a food processor recipe. But good things come to those who werrk/wait/make baked cheesecake. You have to plan ahead a little, as you’ll need to bake it the day before you want to eat it. 

Another note: digestive biscuits are essential for cheesecake heaven. I’ve noticed that most (if not all) American recipes call for graham crackers. They’ll work but results with digestives are better. Digestive biscuits can be found quite easily in the States – large supermarkets have International sections and you’ll often find them there. If not, Indian grocery stores and Amazon also stock them.

Baked cheesecakes without eggs are difficult but this recipe does simplify things. EnerG egg replacer is an absolute godsend – it sets the mixture wonderfully every time.

PS. You could make this as one large baked cheesecake (as pictured) in a 9″ springform tin:

1. Double the recipe.
2. Bake for 45-50 minutes.
3. Switch off oven, then keep it in there for a further 25 before removing.

ingredients:
For the base:
1 1/2 cups digestive biscuit crumbs (approx. 10 biscuits) 
4 tbsp butter, melted

For the blueberry swirl
1 cup blueberries 
1 tsp corn starch
1 tbsp water
1 tbsp sugar
1 tbsp lemon juice

For the cheesecake:
1/2 cup caster sugar
1 cup + 2tbsp cream cheese, brought to room temperature
1/4 cup sour cream
1/2 tsp vanilla bean paste
1 tbsp lemon juice
2 tsp EnerG Egg replacer (corn starch will work if you don't have the egg replacer)
1/2 cup milk

You will need a loose bottomed individual cupcake pan OR a silicone cupcake pan for this recipe.
method:
Make the blueberry sauce:
  1. In a small bowl, whisk together the corn starch, lemon juice and water, then set aside.
  2. Over a medium heat, warm the blueberries and sugar in a non stick saucepan.
  3. Stir continuously for 2-3 minutes until the blueberries begin to release their juice.
  4. Add the corn starch mixture to the blueberries and continue to stir for 2 minutes.
  5. The blueberries will have softened by now so smash most of them as you stir.
  6. As the corn starch heats, the mixture will thicken.
  7. Remove from heat and pour the mixture through a fine mesh strainer.
  8. Retain the whole blueberries for later and set the thickened blueberry sauce to one side.
Make the base:
  1. Break the digestives into halves and thirds. Transfer to a food processor and pulse until they have broken down totally.
  2. Melt the butter and combine with the crumbs.
  3. Press 2 tbsp of the crumb mixture into each cup of the tray. Pack the crumbs tightly.
  4. Preheat your oven to 356F or 180C.
Make the cheesecake:
  1. Combine all the cheesecake ingredients EXCEPT the lemon juice in a mixing bowl. If the cream cheese is still quite solid from the fridge, you may want to use a hand blender to quickly bring the mixture together.
  2. Add the lemon juice and combine.
  3. Sprinkle the cheesecake bases with the whole blueberries you saved from the sauce.
  4. Pour 2 tbsp of the cream cheese mixture into each cup.
  5. Dot each cheesecake with a teaspoon of the blueberry sauce.
  6. Using a skewer, gently swirl the mixture to create a marble effect. Use as much as desired and set the remainder aside for serving with the cheesecake.
  7. Bake the cheesecakes for 15 minutes. They should still have a slight wobble at the centre once baked - it will firm up as it cools.
  8. Switch off the oven, open the door slightly and keep the cheesecake in the oven for a further 7 minutes.
  9. Remove from oven and allow to cool completely at room temperature.
  10. Refrigerate overnight before serving.

posts.title: Vegan Chocolate Blueberry Pudding (Grain-Free, Gluten-Free, Ekadashi)
posts.title_plain: Vegan Chocolate Blueberry Pudding (Grain-Free, Gluten-Free, Ekadashi)
posts.content:
This is an elegant little pudding for any occasion. It’s very rich and chocolatey and the soft, baked blueberries contrast it perfectly. It uses wholesome ingredients and is quick to put together.
If you don’t need it to be grain-free, feel free to use all purpose flour instead of buckwheat. I like the texture and flavour that the almond and coconut bring but you can use just one of them if you like.
Thanks to Karina at Cafe Delites for the inspiration!

ingredients:
Serves 2

For the base:

3-4 tbsp frozen blueberries 
1 tsp brown sugar 

For the pudding: 

2tbsp buckwheat flour
1 tbsp coconut flour
1 tbsp almond meal 
1 tbsp + 1tsp unsweetened cocoa powder
2 tbsp brown sugar (white is fine too)
1 tsp melted coconut oil (or butter)
1/2 cup almond milk (or 1/4 cup milk + 1/4 cup buttermilk)

For the chocolate sauce:

1 tbsp unsweetened cocoa powder
1 tbsp brown sugar
3 tbsp hot water
1 tbsp (extra) hot water
method:
1. Preheat oven to 390F or 200C and keep a baking tray ready.
  2. Grease 2 small ramekins lightly with coconut oil.
  3. Combine the blueberries and raw sugar into the base of each ramekin and set to one side.
  4. In a small mixing bowl, combine the flour, cocoa and sugar. Create a well in the centre, and pour in the coconut oil/butter and the milk.
  5. Top the blueberries with the pudding batter.
  6. Combine the chocolate sauce ingredients and pour a tbsp into each ramekin.
  7. Top each ramekin with 1/2 tbsp of the extra boiling water.
  8. Gently place the ramekins onto the baking tray. Transfer the tray to the oven, taking care that they don't spill over.
  9. Bake the puddings for 15-20 minutes.

posts.title: Blueberry Scones
posts.content:
This is likely the easiest scone recipe you’ll find, enhanced by blueberries and a touch of cinnamon. You could keep them plain if you like, or add something else to add interest – fresh raspberries, orange zest, vanilla beans.

Buttermilk is the key here, by the way. Fluffiest, puffiest, lightest, goldenest scones ever.

Enjoy!

ingredients:
Makes 6 medium sized scones or 9 small scones

1 ½ cups self raising flour
3 ½ tbsp (50g) cold butter, cubed
¼ tsp salt
½ cup buttermilk 
2 tbsp sugar 
½ cup fresh blueberries
¼ tsp ground cinnamon
1-2 tbsp buttermilk, to glaze
1 tbsp turbinado or demerera sugar (optional)
method:
1. Preheat oven to 400F or 200C.
  2. Line a baking tray with parchment.
  3. Add the flour, butter and salt to a food processor.
  4. Pulse until the mixture resembles breadcrumbs.
  5. Transfer the mixture to a mixing bowl and add the sugar, blueberries and cinnamon.
  6. Pour half of the buttermilk into the bowl and use a knife to quickly bring the mixture together.
  7. Add the remaining buttermilk and stir again to form a soft dough.
  8. On a lightly floured surface, very gently knead the dough for 20-30 seconds. It is crucial not to overwork the dough; you just want it to be a smooth ball.
  9. Gently roll the dough to a 2cm thickness. Using a round cookie cutter cut out the scones (a 6cm cutter will give you 6 scones, a 3-4cm cutter, 9).
  10. Lay the scones out on the baking tray, leaving 2 inches between each scone.
  11. Brush each scone with the buttermilk glaze (this is essential - it will ensure the scones are perfectly golden). At this point, you may sprinkle the top of each scone with the turbinado/demerera sugar.
  12. Bake for 15 minutes until golden brown.
  13. Serve warm with grass-fed butter.

posts.title: Vegan Roasted Beetroot Hummus
posts.content:
Beets are just coming into their best at this time of year. They add a ton of nutrients to an already protein-rich dish like hummus: vitamins, antioxidants, dietary fibre and minerals.

Roasting the beet is the only time-consuming element to this. After that, just throw everything into a food processor. The hummus will keep for up to 5 days in the refrigerator.

ingredients:
1 15oz can chickpeas
1 small beetroot
Juice of 1 lemon
Sea salt and cracked black pepper
2 tbsp tahini
1/4 cup olive oil
method:
Roast the beetroot
  1. Preheat your oven to 375F or 190C.
  2. Remove the steam and roots from your beet. Wash and scrub the beet under the tap and peel it.
  3. Cut the beetroot into smaller chunks - 6 or so - and lay on a lined baking tray.
  4. Drizzle with olive oil and roast for 15-20 minutes until the beet is tender.
Make the hummus
  1. While the beet roasts, measure out the remaining ingredients into your food processor.
  2. Once the beet is cooked, allow it to cool for 5-10 minutes before adding to the food processor and pulse until thoroughly combined with the other ingredients. If it seems too thick, you may add 1-2 tbsp of water.
  3. Taste and adjust the seasoning if necessary, adding lemon juice, salt or pepper.
  4. Garnish with a drop of olive oil and fresh herbs.
  5. Serve with pita chips and/or crudités

posts.title: Chocolate Tart (Ekadashi)
posts.content:
This recipe is adapted from the wonderful Sylvie of Gourmande in the Kitchen. It was pretty much flawless and one of the best vegan desserts I’ve had in a while.

The use of coconut milk instead of heavy cream for the ganache is genius. Both heavy cream and coconut milk are indulgent but in my opinion, the coconut adds more flavour without compromising on texture. The crust is so simple to throw together. Of course you can make this as a sweet treat on Ekadashi but honestly, it’s a welcome dessert on any day. Just be sure to serve it with berries – they offset the rich chocolate perfectly.

PS. The tart that’s pictured is a miniature version – I wanted to use my individual tart pan and quartered the recipe.

ingredients:
For the crust:

½ cup unsweetened shredded coconut or coconut flour
1 ½ cups almond flour/meal
2 Tablespoons coconut or olive oil
¼ tsp salt
2 Tablespoons/30 g maple syrup

For the ganache:
1 scant* cup full fat coconut milk
1 3/4 cup soy-free bittersweet chocolate chips 
1 teaspoon vanilla extract

*Use just under a cup 

You will need a 9 inch loose bottomed tart pan for this recipe
method:
Make the tart shell:
    1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees. In a food processor, pulse together almond flour, salt and shredded coconut until finely ground. If using coconut oil, melt it and add to the food processor along with the maple syrup (if using olive oil, add directly). Pulse until coarse crumbs form - you'll know it's ready if you squeeze some in your hands it and it clumps together.
    2. Transfer the mixture to the tart pan. Press the dough evenly into the bottom and sides of the pan. The flat bottom of a measuring cup is helpful to press the crust in.
    3. Bake in the centre of your oven until golden and firm, about 15- 20 minutes.
    4. Once baked, transfer to a wire rack and allow crust to cool completely - one hour minimum
Make the ganache:
    1. Place chocolate in a large mixing bowl.
    2. In a small saucepan, bring the coconut milk to a boil. Pour the hot coconut milk over the chocolate and let it stand for 1 minute, then stir the mixture until smooth and creamy. Mix in the vanilla extract.
Assemble your tart:
  1. Pour the chocolate ganache into the cooled tart shell. Sprinkle with a pinch of flaky sea salt if desired, then chill for at least one hour.
  2. Before serving, garnish with fresh berries and dust with cocoa powder.

posts.title: Vegan Lettuce Wraps
posts.content:
So the method for this recipe looks deceivingly long and complex – it really isn’t. The key things to do are to cut and drain your tofu way before you want to cook it. If it’s watery it won’t crisp up and absorb the flavour of the soy sauce.

Other than that, it’s a piece of cake! The lettuce is the perfect accompaniment to these vibrant and flavourful noodles and ideal for dinner on a summer evening.

If you aren’t serving sweet and sour sauce with the meal, you may want to add a tbsp of brown sugar to the noodles to bring a richer flavour profile to the dish.

ingredients:
Serves 2

1/2 block (7oz) of extra firm tofu (it will crisp up better than less firm tofu)
2 tbsp toasted sesame oil (you can use canola/sunflower if you don't have sesame)
1 tbsp fresh minced ginger
1/2 tbsp minced green chilli 
1 cup shredded cabbage
2 cups assorted vegetables, fresh or frozen or a combination of both (I used corn, green beans, carrots, zucchini, peas)
1/2 cup water chestnuts, chopped
2 tbsp soy sauce
2 tbsp crushed peanuts

2 nests dry wheat noodles (approx 4 oz)

2 tbsp peanut butter
Juice of 1 lime, and more to garnish 
2 tbsp fresh chopped cilantro (coriander) to garnish

1 small head of lettuce, washed and separated into leaves
method:
1. Using a food chopper (like the good ol' Vidalia) cut your slab of tofu into tiny cubes (approx 0.5cm cubes). You can, of course, do this by hand if you don't have a chopper. Let the tofu cubes drain in a sieve/strainer for a minimum of 2 hours.
  2. In a large saucepan, heat the sesame oil over a medium heat.
  3. Add the shredded cabbage, ginger and chilli to the oil and sauté for 5 minutes until the cabbage shreds begin to brown at the edges. It will soften and turn slightly translucent.
  4. Add the vegetables and sauté for a further 5-7 minutes.
  5. Add the chopped water chestnuts and crushed peanuts.
  6. Add the soy sauce and turn the heat down.
  7. Meanwhile, in a frying pan, heat 2 tbsp cooking oil over a medium heat.
  8. Add the tofu cubes to the frying pan and cook for 3-4 minutes on a medium-high heat. Add 2 tbsp of soy sauce over the tofu.
  9. Boil some water in a third pan - enough to submerge the noodles.
  10. Stir the tofu to ensure cooking on all sides. They will brown and crisp up quickly because of their size, so keep an eye on them! Once you're happy with the colour, switch off the heat.
  11. Submerge the noodles in a the pan of boiling water and cook. Depending on the type of noodle, this should not take more than 5 minutes.
  12. Once the noodles have cooked, cut the noodles into thirds - so they're easier to eat!
  13. Transfer the noodles to the vegetable mixture, add the lime juice and combine all the ingredients. Turn the heat up to medium-high.
  14. Add the peanut butter and stir until it has melted and coats the noodles.
  15. Have a taste. Add more lime juice/soy sauce as needed. Garnish with extra crushed peanuts and the cilantro/coriander.
  16. Serve with the tofu, lettuce leaves and sweet and sour sauce.

posts.title: Vegan Chocolate Doughnuts
posts.content: These doughnuts are surprisingly simple to make. I’m not a fan of deep frying, but these really are worth the effort/calories! If you aren’t vegan, you can substitute the vegan cream for heavy whipping cream and the vegan shortening for butter.
posts.excerpt: These doughnuts are surprisingly simple to make. I’m not a fan of deep frying, but these really are worth the effort/calories! If you aren’t vegan, you can substitute the vegan cream for heavy whipping cream and the vegan shortening for butter.

ingredients:
Yield: 12 small doughnuts

2 tbsp granulated sugar
3/4 tsp active dry yeast
1 3/4 cups all-purpose flour
1/2 tsp baking powder
1/4 tsp sea salt
1/4 cup dairy-free cream
1 tbsp vegan shortening/spread 
1/2 cup vegan bittersweet chocolate chips
1/2 cup powdered sugar
1/2 tsp ground cinnamon 
2 cups neutral oil for frying, such as sunflower or canola
method:
1. Combine the yeast and sugar with 1/2 cup of warm water and leave to one side for 10 minutes, until the yeast has begun to foam.
  2. While you wait, measure out the flour, salt and baking powder in a mixing bowl and stir to combine.
  3. In a small saucepan on a low heat, warm the vegan cream and spread until the spread has just melted, then remove from the heat.
  4. Add the cream mixture to the flour mixture and stir until just combined.
  5. Add the yeast mixture to bowl and combine until a dough begins to form.
  6. Knead the dough for a couple of minutes until smooth.
  7. Place the dough in a greased bowl. Cover with cling film and leave in a warm place to rise for 45 minutes.
  8. Once the dough has risen, divide it into 12 equal sized dough balls.
  9. To make a doughnut, flatten one dough ball in the palm of your hand, add approximately 8 chocolate chips to the centre of the ball, then pinch the edges together to seal. Continue for the remaining 11.
  10. Heat your fryer on a low to medium heat. You don't want the oil to smoke, so keep an eye on it.
  11. While it heats, prepare your powdered sugar by sifting it and mixing in the cinnamon powder. Prepare a plate covered with absorbent kitchen paper for the fried doughnuts.
  12. To test if your oil is at the right temperature for frying, place a tiny piece of dough in the oil if it bubbles and stays at the surface, it's ready.
  13. Once your oil is hot enough, fry your doughnuts, 3 at a time. Let them cook for at least 2-3 minutes on each side until golden brown. The outside colour of the doughnut can be deceiving - if they don't cook long enough, you'll be left with raw dough inside.
  14. Once cooked, lay them on the kitchen paper for a minute.
  15. Toss the doughnuts in the powdered sugar and cinnamon and serve immediately

posts.title: Vegan Buckwheat Waffles (Ekadashi)
posts.content:
I just bought my first waffle iron (celebratory dance) and couldn’t wait to use it. So what if it’s ekadashi? I’ll just make some grain-free ones!

This recipe is so wholesome and you can’t tell that they’re wheat-free.

And if you don’t have a waffle iron, you can use this recipe to make buckwheat pancakes.

xo

ingredients:
Yield: 4 small waffles

1/4 cup buckwheat flour
1/2 cup coconut flour
1/4 mashed banana
1 flax egg (1 tbsp flaxmeal +2.5 tbsp water)
pinch of sea salt
pinch of baking soda
1/4 tsp baking powder
1/2 tsp ground cinnamon
1 tbsp raw turbinado sugar (or soft brown sugar)
1 tbsp oil 
1/4 cup + 2 tbsp almond milk
maple syrup and fresh fruit for serving.
method:
1. Prepare your flax egg by mixing 1tbsp flaxmeal with 2.5tbsp water and leave to one side.
  2. In a mixing bowl, measure out the flours, salt, baking powder, baking soda and cinnamon.
  3. Add the mashed banana, almond milk, oil and flax egg.
  4. Whisk to combine.
  5. Heat your waffle iron and brush the plates lightly with oil
  6. Once the waffle iron is hot, pour the batter into the waffle plates and cook until there is no longer steam emitting from the machine.
  7. Serve with maple syrup and fresh fruit.

posts.title: Vegan Basil Pesto
posts.content:
This recipe uses cannellini beans instead of nuts and cheese, which means it can feautre in many healthy meals.The cannellini beans give texture, creaminess and are a good source of protein.

I have omitted Italian hard cheeses like Parmesan and Pecorino because they contain animal rennet.

ingredients:
Yield: 15oz pesto 

1 can cannellini beans 
1 bunch fresh basil, washed
Salt and freshly cracked black pepper
Juice of 1 lemon
3-4 tbsp extra virgin olive oil
Half a jalapeño (optional)
A handful of mint leaves (optional)
method:
1. Drain the beans from the can and rinse them with water.
  2. Add the beans to your food processor and pulse until they stop disintegrating.
  3. Add the herbs, and jalapeño if using. Pulse further.
  4. Add the olive oil and lemon juice. Pulse until the mixture forms a paste. If the paste is too dry, you may add a spoonful of water to the mixture, one tbsp at a time.
  5. Season to taste with salt and pepper.

posts.title: Spaghetti and Wheatballs
posts.content: This is a great way to incorporate extra vegetables into a traditional meal of spaghetti with marinara! The wheatballs add extra flavour, texture and novelty and are very easy to put together.
posts.excerpt: This is a great way to incorporate extra vegetables into a traditional meal of spaghetti with marinara! The wheatballs add extra flavour, texture and novelty and are very easy to put together.

attachments.title: Processed with VSCOcam with f2 preset

ingredients:
Serves 2
Yield: 10 wheatballs 

For the wheatballs:
1 cup sliced mushrooms
1/2 cup cauliflower florets
3/4 cup vegan bread crumbs
1/4 cup walnut halves
1 tsp oregano or Italian seasoning
1 tbsp fresh rosemary, chopped
1/2 tsp salt
Cracked black pepper

2 cups vegan homemade sauce

I used: 
1 can of peeled plum tomatoes
1 large red bell pepper, broiled, blackened, skin peeled and then blended with the plum tomatoes
Salt and cracked black pepper
Dried oregano
A drizzle of extra virgin olive oil 

& 2oz dried spaghetti per person
method:
1. Add the mushrooms and cauliflower to a food processor and pulse.
  2. Add the salt, pepper and herbs.
  3. Add the chopped walnuts and breadcrumbs and blitz until the nuts have disintegrated.
  4. Transfer the mix to a bowl.
  5. Using a cookie scoop to ensure even sized balls, form your wheatballs.
  6. Bring a pan of water to the boil and cook your spaghetti.
  7. While your spaghetti cooks, coat the bottom of a non stick frying pan in your oil of choice.
  8. Cook the wheatballs in the pan, until they are browned on all sides. Drain spaghetti.
  9. Serve with your drained spaghetti and a generous topping of sauce and freshly torn basil.

posts.title: Vegan Thai Green Curry
posts.content:
I am a HUGE fan of Thai food but always struggle to find restaurants that will make it fresh, without fish sauce or shrimp paste. Because shallots and garlic are so crucial to the authentic Thai green curry, it’s near impossible to find a restaurant that will prepare the dish without alliums for you. You can stop looking now though, because this recipe will more than satisfy a hankering for a Thai green curry!

Unlike restaurant versions, this curry is light and tastes clean. The herbs make a beautifully fragrant and flavourful sauce. It departs from the ordinary because it doesn’t taste or feel at all greasy. It’s actually quite pleasant to eat on its own too!

The recipe is easily adaptable in terms of the vegetables you use – snow peas, green beans, peas, sweet potato, mushrooms and broccoli all work well. The beauty of this curry is that you can throw it together quickly with most vegetables that you have at home.

I’m not sure how traditional cashews are in a curry like this, but they do add great texture and flavour.

The paste is enough for a large curry serving 6 people, so you could half it, BUT I highly recommend freezing half of it for another day.

Most of the ingredients are easy to get your hands on – lemongrass is widely available in Asian supermarkets. I found it at Whole Foods.

ingredients:
Serves 2-3

Yield: 1/2 cup curry paste


For the curry paste: 

1 large handful of cilantro (coriander) 
1 thumb of ginger - about an inch square 
1-2 green chillis (feel free to add more if you want a real kick)  
1 stalk lemongrass
1 handful basil leaves
1 tsp crushed black peppercorns
1 tsp toasted cumin seeds, ground
1 tsp coriander seeds, crushed
Juice and zest of 2 limes
2 tsp soy sauce
3 tbsp olive oil


For the curry:
2-3 cups assorted vegetables 
(I used: 10 baby new potatoes, 5 stalks asparagus, 1 carrot, 1/4 cauliflower in florets, 1/2 a Chinese eggplant, 1/2 a zucchini)
1 can coconut milk
2 tsp brown sugar sugar 
Salt to taste 
1/4 cup roasted cashews (optional)
method:
1. To prepare your curry paste, simply blitz all the ingredients in a food processor until it resembles a paste. This is enough paste for 8 people. You may freeze half of it or refrigerate for up to two weeks.
  2. Remove half of the paste and store in an airtight jar or container. Leave the remaining paste in the food processor.
  3. Cook the vegetables using your preferred method. (I steamed the cauliflower, potato and carrot until tender. While they cooked, I sautéed the remaining vegetables in a tablespoon of olive oil on a very hot griddle pan)
  4. Add the can of coconut milk to the food processor and blitz until it has combined into a very pale green sauce. (If you want to add even more veg to your curry, you could throw a generous handful of spinach into the food processor.
  5. Transfer the curry sauce to a sauce pan and bring it to a simmering heat. Add all the vegetables (and cashews if using) to the sauce and cook for a further 2 minutes.
  6. Have a quick taste and add salt or sugar if necessary.
  7. Serve with steamed rice.

posts.title: Raspberry Almond Traybake
posts.content:
This recipe is a family favourite. Raspberries and almonds work really well together. The flavours are reminiscent of a Bakewell tart. Adding ground almonds to the sponge provides extra moisture and flavour to your bake. It also makes the sponge much lighter, which is sometimes difficult to achieve without egg.

Being a traybake, it’s great to make for a large group of people. You can easily double the recipe and bake it in a larger tray, such as a jelly roll pan (13″ x 18″). If not, a 9″x 9″ for a thicker sponge, or 9″ x 13″ work really well.

image1 (3)

ingredients:
For the sponge: 

3/4 cup self raising flour
1/2 cup caster sugar or extra-fine granulated sugar
2 tbsp ground almonds
3/4 tsp baking powder
1/4 tsp baking soda (bicarbonate of soda)
a pinch of salt
1 1/2 tbsp golden syrup
1/2 tbsp vinegar
1/3 cup warm milk
1/4 cup sunflower oil
1/4 tsp almond extract
3/4 - 1 cup raspberries, fresh or frozen - this is really up to you. As little or as much as you like!
Flaked almonds - as above

For the almond glaze:
1/2 cup icing/powdered sugar
3 drops almond extract
1 tbsp milk
method:
1. Preheat your oven to 180C or 350F.
  2. Line your baking tray with baking parchment.
  3. In a mixing bowl, sift the dry ingredients in the following order: sugar, flour, ground almonds, salt, baking soda, baking powder.
  4. Add the golden syrup but avoid placing it on the baking powder and baking soda.
  5. Add the vinegar directly onto the baking powder and soda. The ingredients will react and you’ll see lots of bubbles. This is exactly what you’re looking for.
  6. In quick succession, add the milk and oil.
  7. Mix the ingredients together until smooth. Beat for a further two minutes.
  8. Spoon the mixture into the baking tin. Spread until smooth.
  9. Top with the raspberries, some whole some broken into pieces.
  10. Cover the rest of the sponge with the flaked almonds.
  11. Bake for 20 minutes, until golden and until the top of the cake bounces back when gently pressed.
  12. Let the sponge cool completely before glazing.
  13. Sift the icing sugar into a bowl. Add the remaining ingredients. If you prefer a looser consistency add a tsp more milk. Spoon drizzles of the glaze across the sponge.

posts.title: Vegan Chocolate Almond Granola
posts.content: After moving to the States, I picked up a late-night cereal habit (peer pressure). I accept that there are worse vices but I realised I was consuming so much sugar and wheat. This recipe is the result of trying to counter a Chocolate Toast Crunch addiction. And no offence to those guys over at General Mills, but this stuff is SO much better. It has all the flavour of a chocolatey cereal, but no refined sugar whatsoever. I plan to sprinkle it over warm oatmeal or greek yogurt and berries. This is a very simple, one-bowl recipe. I hope you give it a go!

ingredients:
Yield: 2 cups 

1 cup rolled oats
1/2 unsweetened desiccated coconut
1/2 cup flaked almonds
2 tbsp cocoa powder, heaped
Pinch of salt
1/4 cup maple syrup
2 tbsp liquid coconut oil
1/4 teaspoon almond extract
method:
1. Preheat your oven to 300F or 150C.
  2. Line a baking tray with parchment.
  3. In a mixing bowl, measure out the dry ingredients: oats, coconut, almonds, cocoa, salt.
  4. Combine all the dry ingredients.
  5. Measure out the coconut oil and add the almond extract to it. Stir to combine and then add to the dry ingredients.
  6. Add the maple syrup to the mixture.
  7. Mix thoroughly until all the oats are coated.
  8. Spread the granola mixture onto the baking tray.
  9. Bake for 15 minutes. Remove the tray from the oven and stir the mixture to ensure even baking.
  10. Return the tray to the oven for a further 12 minutes.
  11. Switch off the oven but leave the tray inside to allow the granola to dry.
  12. Remove from the oven and let the granola dry further and cool for 20 minutes.
  13. The granola will keep for up to 2 weeks in an airtight container.

posts.title: Vegan Chocolate Chip Cookies with Salted Popcorn
posts.title_plain: Vegan Chocolate Chip Cookies with Salted Popcorn
posts.content:
I really wasn’t expecting these cookies to turn out as good as they did. I mean come on! Chocolate chip cookies sans butter?! Before this recipe, I would have called that sacrilege. Turns out it’s a winner! These cookies are slightly crisp at the edge and soft and chewy at the centre. They have the subtlest hint of coconut running through them and need I go on about the merits of salty and sweet in a cookie? Salted popcorn + semi-sweet chocolate are long lost lovers, I’m sure of it.

Best of all, this recipe is 100% vegan (not that you can tell). Just be sure to use vegan chocolate chips – they’re easily found at Whole Foods and this useful guide by PETA offers other options.

I know it seems a pain, but chilling this cookie dough before baking is not optional. Coconut oil has a different consistency to butter so it must chill before it gets baked. The results are totally worth it, I promise!

Happy baking xo

ingredients:
Yield: 18 small cookies or 12 medium-sized 

1 1/2 cups all purpose flour
1/2 cup brown sugar, packed firm in the cup
1/3 cup granulated sugar
1/2 tsp salt
1 tsp baking powder
1 tsp baking soda
1/2 cup liquid coconut oil
1/4 cup pureed tofu
1-2 tbsp almond milk
1/2 cup vegan semisweet chocolate chips
1/4 cup salted popcorn
method:
1. In a mixing bowl, measure out the flour, sugars, salt, baking powder and baking soda.
  2. Add the pureed tofu and coconut. Stir until you have a crumbly, sand-like dough.
  3. Add 1 tbsp of the almond milk and combine. Only add a second if you feel the dough is excessively dry.
  4. Fold in the popcorn with a spatula.
  5. Fold in the chocolate chips.
  6. Shape the dough into balls of equal size.
  7. Place the dough balls on a lined baking tray, cover with cling film and refrigerate for at least 2 hours, but up to two days.
  8. When you're ready to bake, preheat your oven to 350F or 180C.
  9. Place the cookies on a lined baking tray and space them 2 inches apart.
  10. Bake for 10-12 minutes until the edges are slightly golden. The centres will still be soft.
  11. Let the cookies cool on the baking tray for 10 minutes and then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely.
  12. The cookies will keep in an airtight container for up to 5 days.

posts.title: Cheddar Buttermilk Scones
posts.content:
These scones are really quick to put together – 30 mins start to finish. And the finish involves warm scones oozing with cheddar. It’s a good finish if you ask me. The jalapeño adds a good kick of spice but you can add or subtract the amount according to your spice preference.

I hope you enjoy them!

ingredients:
Yield: makes 8 scones
1 2/3 cup self-raising flour
1/2 tsp salt 
Freshly ground black pepper
1/4 cup or half a stick butter, grated
3/4 cup sharp cheddar, grated or cubed + more for sprinkling
1/4 cup jarred jalapeño slices 
1 tbsp juice from jalapeño jar
2/3 cup buttermilk 
Buttermilk to glaze
method:
1. Preheat oven to 390F or 200C.
  2. Mix the flour and salt together.
  3. Add the grated butter and rub it in until the mixture resembles fine crumbs.
  4. Add half of the cheddar to the mixture along with the jalapeños.
  5. Make a well in the centre of the mixture and pour in the buttermilk.
  6. Swiftly stir the mixture until it comes together to form a soft dough.
  7. Knead the dough for a couple of minutes on a lightly floured surface.
  8. Roll the dough out to a 1 inch thick square.
  9. Quarter the dough into 4 squares, then cut each square diagonally. This will give you 8 triangles of dough.
  10. Measure out a tablespoon of buttermilk on a small plate and brush the scones with it.
  11. Sprinkle more cheddar atop the scones if desired, then bake for 12-14 minutes until they have puffed up and are golden brown.

posts.title: Grain-Free ‘Quinola’
posts.content:
This recipe is perfect if you’re looking for a protein-rich and filling breakfast option. It also happens to be totally grain-free and therefore ideal for paleo diets and ekadashi.

It is simple to put together and freezes well, so why not make a big batch and take out a small serving as and when you need it?

The recipe is pretty versatile so you could substitute other ingredients quite easily. For example, you could also use sesame seeds, walnuts, or dried apricots. Make it your own!

I suggest serving the quinola with fresh fruit, Greek yogurt and toasted coconut flakes.

attachments.title: IMG_6124.JPG

ingredients:
Yield: 1 generous cup, serves 2-3

1/4 cup uncooked quinoa
1/4 cup chopped pecans
1/4 cup chopped almonds 
2 tbsp sunflower seeds
1 tbsp flax seeds
1 tsp coconut oil, melted
2 tbsp maple syrup 
a pinch of cinnamon
method:
1. Preheat your oven to 350F/180C and line a baking tray with parchment. Combine all the dry ingredients EXCEPT the dried fruit in a mixing bowl.
  2. Add the syrup and melted oil and stir thoroughly.
  3. Spread the mixture onto your lined baking tray. Keep it at the centre of the tray rather than spreading it too thin - it will burn easily if you do this.
  4. Bake for 7 minutes, then stir the mixture to ensure even baking.
  5. Bake for a further 8 minutes until golden brown.
  6. Let the mixture cool on the tray. You may have to break the mixture up into smaller clusters, it really depends on your preference.
  7. If using, add the dried fruit to your quinola.
  8. Enjoy!

posts.title: Vegan Lemon Loaf Cake
posts.content:
After a week in New Jersey, I’m back in England. And unlike New Jersey which saw snow just a few days ago, there are daffodils and blossom everywhere in London. This recipe is lovely for springtime; it is light, and full of zesty lemon.

This recipe is vegan, however you could substitute the nut milk for dairy milk if you prefer.

I decorated mine with caramelised lemon slices. If you’d like to do the same, simply slice a lemon finely with a mandolin, make a simple caramel and caramelise the lemon slices on each side for 15-20 seconds. Let them cool before topping the loaf cake.

Happy Baking!

ingredients:
For the loaf cake:
1 3/4 cup self-raising flour
1/2 cup caster sugar or extra-fine granulated sugar
1/4 tsp salt
1 1/2 tsp baking powder 
1/2 tsp bicarbonate of soda / baking soda
1/4 cup desiccated coconut
3 tbsp brown rice syrup or golden syrup
1 tbsp apple cider vinegar
3/4 cup + 2 tbsp unsweetened almond milk
1/2 cup sunflower oil 


For the lemon glaze:
1/2 cup icing/powdered sugar
Zest and juice of 1 small lemon or 1/2 a large lemon
method:
1. Preheat your oven to 350F or 180C.
  2. Line your loaf tin with baking parchment.
  3. In a mixing bowl or the bowl of your stand mixer, sift the first 5 ingredients in the above order (flour to baking powder).
  4. Add the coconut and syrup.
  5. Add the vinegar, which will react with the bicarbonate of soda.
  6. Swiftly add the almond milk and oil.
  7. Mix the ingredients together until you have a smooth cake batter. If you feel it is too thick, you may add up to 2 more tbsp of milk.
  8. Pour the cake batter into the lined tin. Ensure it is spread evenly.
  9. Bake for 25 minutes.
  10. Tear a piece of foil large enough to cover the tin. Quickly and gently remove the cake from the oven and cover with the foil.
  11. Return to oven for a further 20 minutes.
  12. To be sure the cake has baked all the way through, pierce with a skewer. If it comes out clean, it's ready.
  13. Allow the cake to cool totally before icing.
  14. Make the icing by sifting the icing/powdered sugar and adding the juice and zest. Mix until smooth.
  15. Remove the cake from the tin.
  16. Using a piping bag* ice the cake as you wish. I like to just zigzag across repeatedly. *You could also just fill a ziploc bag with the icing, snip a tiny part of the corner off, and use that.

posts.title: Potato Chip Cookies
posts.content:
After 6 months in the States, I returned to London the other week. It was so good to be home! Unsurprisingly, within hours of arriving I couldn’t help but bake something in the kitchen I’d grown up in — using the oven that has seen many a triumph and MANY a failure over the years. I can confidently say that these cookies were a total triumph, mostly because they’re adapted from the infallible Izy Hossack of Top With Cinnamon. I used tofu to replace the egg, which keeps the cookies moist and chewy.

I took these cookies to a dinner party and everyone loved them. A couple of points:

Yes, there really are potato chips/crisps in these cookies.
Yes, they taste amazing!

Dark chocolate and sea salt cookies are hugely popular at the moment; this is a quirky alternative. The potato chips/crisps permeate the whole cookie and offer a very subtle note of saltiness (sometimes a sprinkle on top of the cookie is a bit much for some people – not me!).

I know it sounds crazy, but this not-so-secret ingredient is a great addition to your cookie dough. I hope you’ll give it a try.

Unsurprisingly, within hours of arriving I couldn’t help but bake something in the kitchen I’d grown up in — using the oven that has seen many a triumph and MANY a failure over the years. I can … Continue reading Potato Chip Cookies

categories.title: Recipe
categories.description: This is where you add new recipes to the site.

ingredients:
Yield: makes 15 small cookies

10 tbsp butter
1 3/4 cup plain / all purpose flour 
3/4 tsp baking powder
3/4 tsp baking soda
1/2 cup granulated sugar
1/2 cup + 1 1/2 tbsp light brown sugar
1/2 tsp salt
1 1/2 tbsp soft-medium tofu
1/2 cup ready salted potato chips/crisps, crushed
90g dark chocolate, chopped into chunks
method:
1. Melt the butter in a saucepan over a low-medium heat. It will melt, then bubble and foam. Once it darkens slightly and begins to smell nutty, remove from the heat and allow to cool for ten minutes.
  2. In a large bowl or the bowl of your stand mixer, measure out the flour, baking soda, baking powder, salt and sugars. If you aren't using a stand mixer, mix the ingredients in the bowl.
  3. Pour in the melted butter gradually.
  4. Break the tofu down until it is totally mushy and add it to the bowl.
  5. Stir the ingredients until it resembles a slightly crumbly, sandy dough.
  6. Fold in the chocolate and potato chips/crisps.
  7. Form your cookies, approximately 2 tbsp per cookie.
  8. Refrigerate the dough in an airtight container for at least 2 hours (but you can do so for up to 3 days - the longer the better).
  9. Once you're ready to bake them, preheat the oven to 180C or 350F.
  10. Line a baking tray with parchment and place the cookies on it, spacing them 2-3 inches apart.
  11. Bake for 13-15 minutes. They will have spread, puffed up slightly and should be ever so slightly golden.
  12. Let them cool on the baking tray for 5 minutes before transferring to a wire rack.

posts.title: Passion Fruit Layer Cake
posts.content:
I made this cake recently for my cousin’s birthday. It was the first time I combined these two flavours and they are a match made in heaven! The coconut sponge sandwiches a vanilla bean mascarpone and passion fruit. The sharp tang of the fruit is perfect with the creamy vanilla mascarpone.

This cake is great for a special occasion — unusual flavours, simple to make and very eye-catching.

You will need two 8 inch cake tins for this recipe.
posts.excerpt: I made this cake recently for my cousin’s birthday. It was the first time I combined these two flavours and they are a match made in heaven! The coconut sponge sandwiches a vanilla bean mascarpone and passion fruit. The sharp tang of the fruit is perfect with the creamy vanilla mascarpone. This cake is great for … Continue reading Passion Fruit Layer Cake

categories.title: Recipe
categories.description: This is where you add new recipes to the site.

attachments.title: image2

ingredients:
For the coconut sponge: 

1 3/4 cup self-raising flour
1/2 cup caster sugar or extra-fine granulated sugar
1 1/2 tsp baking powder 
1/2 tsp bicarbonate of soda / baking soda
1/4 tsp salt
3 tbsp golden syrup
3/4 + 2 tbsp warm milk 
1 tbsp vinegar
1/2 cup sunflower oil 
1/4 cup desiccated coconut

For the filling: 
4 passion fruits
150g mascarpone 
150g fromage frais*
1 tbsp caster sugar / extra-fine granulated sugar
1/2 tsp vanilla bean paste


*I haven't found fromage frais in US supermarkets, although it may well be available. I would suggest substituting low fat cream cheese or non-fat greek yogurt if you can't find it.
method:
1. Preheat your oven to 180C or 350F.
  2. Line your two 8 inch cake tins with baking parchment.
  3. In a mixing bowl, sift the dry ingredients in the following order: sugar, flour, salt, baking soda, baking powder, coconut
  4. Add the golden syrup but avoid placing it on the baking powder and baking soda. If you haven't already, warm the milk.
  5. Add the vinegar directly onto the baking powder and soda. The ingredients will react and you’ll see lots of bubbles. This is exactly what you’re looking for.
  6. In quick succession, add the milk and oil.
  7. Mix the ingredients together until smooth. Beat for a further two minutes.
  8. Divide the cake batter evenly between the two cake tins.
  9. Ensure that the cake batter is evenly spread in the tins, so that they bake evenly.
  10. Bake for 20 minutes, until the sponges are golden. If you press the top of the sponge gently it ought to bounce back up. Alternatively, pierce with a skewer. If it comes out clean, the sponge is cooked all the way through.
  11. Let the sponges sit for 10 minutes before removing them from their tins. This will accelerate the cooling time. They must be at room temperature when you assemble the cake. If you aren't in a hurry, let them cool in the baking tins for 2-3 hours.
  12. When you're ready to assemble, combine the mascarpone, sugar, fromage frais and vanilla bean paste.
  13. Halve one passion fruit and add it's flesh to the mascarpone mixture.
  14. Halve the rest of the passion fruits and empty out the flesh and juice into a small bowl. Decide which sponge cake will be your bottom layer. Spoon approximately 5 tsp of the passionfruit juice onto the top of your bottom layer.
  15. Spoon the mascarpone mixture onto the centre of your cake, leaving the outer 1.5 inches untouched - the mixture will spread outwards when you place the other sponge on top.
  16. Now add the remaining passion fruit flesh onto the mascarpone mixture. Let this come to the edge of the cake, it looks so beautiful.
  17. Place the top layer of the cake carefully so that they are in line with one another.
  18. Refrigerate your cake. Remove from the fridge 10 minutes before serving.
  19. Dust with icing sugar just before serving.

posts.title: Brown Butter Blondies
posts.content:
These blondies are the most indulgent and heavenly thing I have baked in a long time. There’s absolutely nothing virtuous about this recipe but when you bite into one, you’ll lose your mind and won’t care.

Blondies are basically brownies made without the cocoa and require brown sugar rather than white so the sweetness is deeper, more treacly.

Please do use vanilla bean paste if you can, it seriously makes a huge difference in this recipe; there are so few ingredients so you can really taste it.

I used very dark chocolate – 85% cocoa solids – and it cuts through the sugar and butter perfectly. You could substitute milk or white if you dislike bittersweet chocolate.

You’d be very silly not to give these a go, I promise.

As with regular brownies, they are at their best and fudgiest on the day you bake them. However, they will keep for up to 3 days in an airtight container.
