Blondies are basically brownies made without the cocoa and require brown sugar rather than white so the sweetness is … Continue reading Brown Butter Blondies

categories.title: Recipe
categories.description: This is where you add new recipes to the site.

attachments.title: image1 (1)
image2 (1)
image3

ingredients:
1 cup butter
1 1/4 cups light brown sugar
1 tsp salt
2 cups flour
2/3 cup soft-medium tofu
1 tsp vanilla bean paste
1 cup dark chocolate, cut into small chunks
method:
1. Cut your butter into cubes of approximately equal size - this will allow it all to melt at the same rate.
  2. Melt the butter in a saucepan over a low to medium heat.
  3. Swirl it around in the pan, and cook for 3-4 minutes until it starts to smell nutty.
  4. Pour the butter into a medium sized mixing bowl and set aside.
  5. Preheat your oven to 180C or 350F. Line a square 8 inch x 8 inch baking tin with parchment paper.
  6. In a small bowl, mash your tofu down until it is totally broken down. Mix in the vanilla bean paste.
  7. Add the brown sugar to the bowl of butter and mix for 30 seconds with a wooden spoon.
  8. Add the tofu/vanilla mixture to the butter/sugar mixture and stir for 30 seconds.
  9. Add the flour and salt to the butter/sugar/tofu mixture and combine slowly.
  10. When there are still a few pockets of flour remaining, fold in the chocolate chunks.
  11. As soon as it is all combined, pour the mix into your lined tin.
  12. Using your wooden spoon, pat it down to ensure it is distributed evenly.
  13. Bake for 25-27 minutes. You can't do a skewer test with this recipe but the blondies will be firm at the edges and ever so slightly browned.
  14. Remove from oven and allow to cool for at least 15 minutes before attempting to cut - it won't cut cleanly if you do it too soon.
  15. That said, these are DIVINE when still warm so don't wait too long!

posts.title: Triple Chocolate Muffins
posts.content:
These muffins will always satisfy one of those irrational need-chocolate-NOW cravings. Loaded with bitter cocoa, white chocolate and 70% cocoa dark chocolate, they’re rich and comforting.
This is also a super quick, one bowl recipe so you should be in and out of the kitchen in 30 minutes!
posts.excerpt: These muffins will always satisfy one of those irrational need-chocolate-NOW cravings. Loaded with bitter cocoa, white chocolate and 70% cocoa dark chocolate, they’re rich and comforting. This is also a super quick, one bowl recipe so you should be in and out of the kitchen in 30 minutes!

categories.title: Recipe
categories.description: This is where you add new recipes to the site.

ingredients:
Yield: 6 large muffins

3/4 cup self raising flour
2 tbsp unsweetened cocoa 
1/4 cup caster sugar/ extra-fine granulated sugar
1/4 tsp baking soda (bicarbonate of soda)
3/4 tsp baking powder 
a pinch of salt
1 1/2 tbsp golden syrup (if you don't have golden syrup, you could substitute honey)
6 tbsp warm milk
1/4 cup sunflower oil or other neutral oil
1/2 tbsp vinegar 
White and dark chocolate, 25g of each
method:
1. Preheat your oven to 180C or 350F.
  2. Line a 6 cup muffin tray with paper cases.
  3. Chop your white and dark chocolate into chunks.
  4. In a mixing bowl, sift the dry ingredients in the following order: cocoa, sugar, flour, salt, baking soda, baking powder.
  5. Add the golden syrup but avoid placing it on the baking powder and baking soda.
  6. Add the vinegar directly onto the baking powder and soda. The ingredients will react and you’ll see lots of bubbles. This is exactly what you’re looking for.
  7. In quick succession, add the milk and oil.
  8. Mix the ingredients together until smooth. Beat for a further two minutes.
  9. Spoon the muffin mixture into the cases, distributing it evenly between the 6 - about 2 generous tablespoons per muffin.
  10. Top each muffin with the white and dark chocolate chunks.
  11. Bake the muffins for 16 minutes. When the top of the muffin is pressed gently, it should bounce back up. If it doesn't cook for a further 2 minutes, until it does bounce back.

posts.title: Banana Blueberry Bread
posts.content:
Banana bread. Super quick to put together, it wafts insanely good bake-y smells all around the house. But what if one of you prefers blueberry bread? YOU MAKE THEM BOTH IN ONE TIN, THAT’S WHAT.

Introducing the Best of Both Banana Blueberry Buttermilk Breakfast-Friendly Bread.

There’s mashed banana running  through one side and for banana fiends, a thinly sliced banana baked into the top of it (which makes all the difference). And for those partial to tart blueberries, slice into the other side.

The fruit in this recipe does have a lot of sugar in it so there’s only 1/2 cup sugar. If you prefer your bakes on the sweeter side, add a couple of tablespoons of golden/maple syrup.

I’ve only recently begun baking with buttermilk and I’m totally converted (buttermilk pancake recipe coming soon – buttermilk in everything, always). It is slightly acidic and therefore reacts with the baking soda in the oven and creates a super moist and fluffy loaf. If you don’t have buttermilk, substitute regular milk with a tbsp of vinegar. Mix and leave for 10 minutes before using. That said, if you can find buttermilk, it’s so worth it.

YOU MAKE THEM BOTH IN ONE TIN, THAT’S WHAT. Introducing the Best of Both Banana Blueberry Buttermilk Breakfast-Friendly Bread. There’s mashed banana running  through one side and for banana … Continue reading Banana Blueberry Bread

categories.title: Recipe
categories.description: This is where you add new recipes to the site.

attachments.title: FullSizeRender (1)

ingredients:
1 3/4 cups self-raising flour (you can use whole wheat but expect a denser texture) 
1/2 cup caster sugar/extra fine granulated sugar 
1 1/2 tsp baking powder
1/2 tsp baking soda 
1/4 tsp salt
1 cup buttermilk
1/2 cup sunflower oil (or another neutral oil)
1/2 tsp ground cinnamon 
1/2 banana, mashed
1/2 banana sliced lengthways (for the top of the bread)
1/2 cup blueberries
method:
1. Preheat your oven to 350F or 180C.
  2. Line a loaf tin with baking parchment.
  3. In a medium sized bowl mash the banana and leave to one side.
  4. In a second bowl (or the bowl of your stand mixer) sift the flour, baking powder, baking soda and salt into a bowl or the bowl of your stand mixer.
  5. Add in the oil, buttermilk and cinnamon. Mix until smooth.
  6. Pour half of the mix into the bowl wish the mashed banana and combine.
  7. Fold in the blueberries - leaving a few aside - to the plain mix.
  8. Carefully pour the banana mix to one side of the loaf tin.
  9. Transfer the blueberry mix to the other side of the loaf tin.
  10. Arrange the sliced banana atop the banana side and stud the other half with remaining blueberries.
  11. Bake for 50-55 minutes. Use a skewer or sharp knife and pierce the cake to the bottom of the tin. If it comes out clean, it's cooked all the way through. If it's nearly there, switch off the oven and leave it in there for 5 minutes before removing.
  12. Allow the loaf to cool for at least 15 minutes before gobbling.

posts.title: Individual Brownie Cheesecakes (Ekadashi)
posts.content:
Guys! I’ve never been good at maths but the following formula is 100% correct:
Grain-free brownies + egg-free brownies – refined sugar = PERFECT GUILT FREE BROWNIES (that can also be made for Ekadashi).

Yup, that’s right. Honestly they’re super scrummy without the cheesecake topping. But I’m not gonna be that girl who said cheesecake is unnecessary. So make them with the cheesecake topping, ok?

A few things to mention:

  • I used silicone moulds like these for this recipe and would recommend you do the same. If you don’t have silicone moulds, a mini muffin tray lined with muffin cases would work just as well.
  • When I say individual, I really do mean tiny – maybe 1 square inch. If you want bigger morsels, simply double/treble the recipe and use a cupcake tray.
  • Buckwheat is absolutely not a grain, and can be consumed on Ekadashi.
  • There are only two brownies in the photos because the others were gobbled quite early on. No regrets and no apologies.

Yup, that’s right. Honestly they’re super scrummy without the cheesecake topping. But I’m not gonna be that girl who said cheesecake is … Continue reading Individual Brownie Cheesecakes (Ekadashi)

categories.title: Recipe
categories.description: This is where you add new recipes to the site.

attachments.title: FullSizeRender
FullSizeRender-3

ingredients:
Yield: makes 12 bite-size cheesecakes

For the base: 

1 tbsp and 1 tsp coconut oil, melted
1/4 cup maple syrup 
1 tsp baking powder
1/2 tsp of salt
1/4 cup ground almonds
4 tsp buckwheat flour 
1/4 cup cocoa powder
1 tbsp and 1 tsp almond milk 

For the cheesecake:

100g cream cheese
28ml sour cream 
1 tbsp sugar
1 tbsp + 1 tsp  Ener-G egg replacer (a combination of potato and tapioca starch)
2 tbsp almond milk
method:
1. Preheat oven to 350F.
  2. Prepare your brownie moulds - silicone baking moulds are ideal because the brownies can be removed more easily. If you don't have them, you could use cupcake cases in a cupcake tray.
  3. In a bowl combine the melted coconut oil and maple syrup.
  4. In succession, add the salt, baking powder, flour and cocoa.
  5. Fold in the ground almonds.
  6. Add in the almond milk and mix until you have a smooth brownie mix.
  7. Divide the brownie mixture between 12 cases or moulds.
  8. Bake for 6 minutes.
  9. Remove from oven and allow to cool.
  10. Combine all the cheesecake ingredients together.
  11. Top the brownies with the cheesecake mixture - between 1 1/2 and 2 tsp per brownie - and spread smoothly and as flat as possible.
  12. Return your moulds to the oven for 10 minutes.
  13. Switch off your oven BUT leave the cheesecakes in there for a further 5 minutes.
  14. Remove from oven and allow to cool to room temperature.
  15. Refrigerate the cheesecakes for at least 2 hours. (If using silicone moulds, use the freezer for 45 minutes. They'll pop out of the moulds easily)
  16. Remove the cheesecake from the moulds and serve.

posts.title: Vegan Coconut Macaroons (Ekadashi)
posts.content:
This recipe produces coconut macaroons that are:
a) vegan
b) grain-free
c) refined sugar-free

The macaroons are soft and chewy and the process is really simple. You’ll be done in 30 mins, start to finish!

I chose to make tiny macaroons (just one tbsp per cookie) but if you divide this recipe into 8 you’ll get much chunkier cookies than those pictured.

You’ll be done in 30 mins, start to finish! I chose to make tiny macaroons (just one tbsp per cookie) but if you divide this recipe into 8 you’ll get much chunkier … Continue reading Vegan Coconut Macaroons (Ekadashi)

categories.title: Recipe
categories.description: This is where you add new recipes to the site.

ingredients:
Yield: makes 8 macaroons

1/2 cup + 1tbp unsweetened desiccated coconut
1/2 cup reduced fat coconut milk
1 tablespoon almond meal
2 tbsp maple syrup
Pinch of salt
1 tsp potato/tapioca starch
25g dark chocolate - minimum 70% cocoa solids - for drizzling (optional)
method:
1. Preheat your oven to 350F/180C.
  2. Line a baking tray with parchment.
  3. Add the coconut milk and maple syrup to a saucepan on a medium heat and stir.
  4. Add the coconut, salt, almond meal and salt.
  5. Add the starch and combine.
  6. Once it has come together, cook for 1 minute, then remove from heat.
  7. Spoon tablespoonfuls of mixture into mounds onto the parchment. Use 2 tablespoons per mound. They will spread as they cook so keep them round and compact. Also be sure to space the macaroons 3 inches apart.
  8. Bake for 12-14 minutes until the macaroons are golden at the edges.
  9. Let the cookies cool on the tray for approximately 10 minutes.
  10. Prepare your chocolate drizzle if using and in the mean time, refrigerate the macaroons.
  11. Break the chocolate into pieces and place in a microwaveable bowl. Microwave in 30 second increments, stirring each time until your chocolate is melted.
  12. Remove the macaroons from the refrigerator. Dip a spoon into the melted chocolate and drizzle over the macaroons.
  13. Gently lift them from the parchment once the chocolate has fully dried.

posts.title: Carrot Cake Doughnuts
posts.content:
Oh, I love me some doughnuts. All the doughnuts are my friends. That said, deep-fried dough on the reg probably isn’t advisable so this baked carrot cake variety is a winner. The recipe is adapted from Sainsbury’s Magazine.

Because they aren’t fried or yeasted like authentic doughnuts, they have a more cake-like structure. However, they are just as yummy! And ever so slightly less sinful. These doughnuts are laden with spices, the walnuts and carrots offer texture and the slightly tart cream cheese frosting is a perfect accompaniment.

You will need a doughnut pan for this recipe.

That said, deep-fried dough on the reg probably isn’t advisable so this baked carrot cake variety is a winner. The recipe is adapted from Sainsbury’s Magazine. Because they aren’t fried or yeasted like authentic doughnuts, they have a more cake-like structure. However, they are just as … Continue reading Carrot Cake Doughnuts

categories.title: Recipe
categories.description: This is where you add new recipes to the site.

ingredients:
Yield: makes 6 doughnuts or 12 mini doughnuts

For the doughnuts: 
75ml buttermilk* 
45g coconut oil
75g all purpose or whole wheat flour
1 tsp baking powder
1 tsp ground cinnamon
½ tsp ground ginger
½ tsp grated nutmeg
a pinch of salt
45g caster sugar or extra fine granulated sugar
2 tbsp maple syrup
1 egg's worth of egg substitute (I used EnerG egg replacer and used as directed)
75g carrot, finely grated
25g walnut pieces, chopped

*or 75ml of milk with 2 tsp of lemon juice and left for 10 minutes before use

For the cream cheese frosting:

50g cream cheese, at room temperature
15g unsalted butter, softened
40g powdered/icing sugar
2 tsp maple syrup
1 tbsp lemon juice
method:
1. Preheat your oven to 356F or 180C.
  2. Grease your doughnut pan.
  3. Measure out the flour, spices, baking powder and salt to a mixing bowl.
  4. Melt the coconut oil and add to it the maple syrup and sugar.
  5. Prepare your egg substitute and add it to the dry ingredients.
  6. Add the coconut oil mixture to the mixing bowl, along with the carrots and buttermilk.
  7. Combine the ingredients but avoid stirring excessively. Once it's a smooth batter, you can stop.
  8. Using a piping bag (or a Ziploc sandwich bag), pipe the batter into the doughnut pan.  (Put the piping bag into a large mug and fold it over the edges of the mug. Fill the bag to the top of the mug and then remove).
  9. For a 12 cavity mini doughnut pan, bake for 8 minutes. For a 6 cavity doughnut pan, bake for 10-12 minutes. If you gently press a doughnut, it should bounce back up if cooked.
  10. Once cooked, remove from the oven. After 5 minutes, transfer to a wire rack to cool. Turn them out so that the underside of the doughnuts are facing up. This is the side you will want to frost.
  11. While they cool, prepare your frosting. In a small bowl, whisk together all the ingredients.
  12. Once the doughnuts are cool, frost.

posts.title: Vegan Crêpes
posts.content:
Crêpes are super versatile. With a basic sweet crêpe recipe, you can be as imaginative and adventurous as you like with toppings and fillings. Some ideas:

  1. Nutella
  2. Roasted banana and Nutella
  3. Warm fruit compote
  4. Just a little lemon juice and powdered sugar.
  5. Fresh strawberries and flaked almonds
  6. Stewed apple with cinnamon

I didn’t think crêpes would be easy to replicate without egg, but these ticked all the boxes. They’re delicately thin and therefore lighter than having a stack of pancakes. They’re slightly sweet, soft in the middle and crisper at the edges. Give them a go!

Some ideas: Nutella Roasted banana and Nutella Warm fruit compote Just a little lemon juice and powdered sugar. Fresh strawberries and flaked almonds Stewed apple with cinnamon I didn’t think crêpes would … Continue reading Vegan Crêpes

categories.title: Recipe
categories.description: This is where you add new recipes to the site.

attachments.title: FullSizeRender-2

ingredients:
Yield: makes 6 crêpes

3/4 cup all purpose flour
2 tsp brown sugar
1/2 tsp baking powder
1 tsp neutral oil, such as sunflower
1 pinch of salt
1 cup almond milk
Oil for cooking (optional - if you have a good non stick pan you may not need any)
method:
1. Combine all your ingredients together in a bowl. Whisk until smooth.
  2. Heat an oiled non stick frying pan over a medium heat.
  3. Pour one small ladle of batter into the centre of the pan and gently twirl the pan to spread the batter around the pan to make a larger circle.
  4. Cook for 2 minutes, until the top side of thecrêpe is totally dry.
  5. Flip the crêpe and cook for 2 more minutes until slightly golden.
  6. Serve warm with choice of filling.

posts.title: Loved Up Cinnamon Rolls
posts.content:
Cinnamon rolls (mmm). Little cinnamon rolls (aww). Little heart-shaped cinnamon rolls with a maple glaze (yeahhs).

These rolls are simple to make and with a slight variation in rolling technique, the classic spirals of dough transform into adorable hearts. They add some novelty and are rather yummy if I do say so myself.

May I also suggest that one day you replace the cinnamon filling with Nutella? You will not regret it!

Bonne Baking! xo

Yield: makes 20 miniature rolls

They add some novelty and are rather yummy if I do say so myself. May I also suggest … Continue reading Loved Up Cinnamon Rolls

categories.title: Recipe
categories.description: This is where you add new recipes to the site.

ingredients:
For the dough:

1 1/4 cup all-purpose flour
1 1/2 tbsp granulated sugar
1/2 tsp salt
1 1/4 tsp active dry yeast
1/4 cup water
1/2 cup milk
1 tbsp + 1 tsp unsalted butter

For the filling:

1 tbsp + 1 tsp unsalted butter, softened to room temperature (it needs to be spreadable)
1.5 tsp ground cinnamon
¼ cup brown sugar 

For the glaze:
2 tbsp powdered sugar
1/2 tsp maple syrup
1 1/4 tsp milk
method:
1. Measure out the dry ingredients into a bowl.
  2. Heat your milk and water to approximately 115F. The warmth is necessary to activate the yeast. Avoid scalding water, is this will kill the yeast.
  3. Stir the milk, water and melted butter into the flour mixture.
  4. Combine until you have a soft dough.
  5. It should have an elastic feel to it and come away clean from the sides of the bowl.
  6. Knead your dough for 3 minutes on a floured surface.
  7. Divide the dough into 2 balls.
  8. Place the dough balls in a bowl, cover and leave to one side for 10 minutes.
  9. In the mean time, make your filling. Combine the cinnamon and sugar in a bowl.
  10. Line 2 baking trays with parchment.
  11. After ten minutes, roll out one dough ball on a floured surface to a rectangle approximately 9x11 inches.
  12. Warm your coconut oil if it’s solid, and spread half of it onto the dough.
  13. Sprinkle half of the sugar and cinnamon mixture evenly across the dough.
  14. Using a pizza slicer cut the edges of your dough so that you're left with an even rectangle. This will ensure your hearts are even.
  15. Roll the longer sides of the rectangle towards each other carefully.
  16. Stop when both sides meet in the middle.
  17. Dab a drop of water in between where the two coils meet and press the sides together gently.
  18. Cut the dough into ten evenly sized rolls, using the pizza slicer.
  19. To make the heart shape, simply pinch the bottom of the roll into a point.
  20. Repeat steps 11-19 with the second dough ball.
  21. Place the 20 hearts on the 2 baking trays, leaving 3 inches between each one. Cover loosely with foil or cling film and leave the rolls to rest for at least 60 minutes in a warm place. They should swell slightly.
  22. Preheat your oven to 356F or 180C.
  23. Bake for 15-17 minutes, until the undersides are golden brown.
  24. Remove from the oven and let the rolls cool on the tray.
  25. Make the glaze by combining the three ingredients.
  26. Once your rolls have cooled, drizzle the glaze over each one.
  27. Devour.

posts.title: Marble Cake
posts.content:
Marble cake is pretty isn’t it? So clever and swirly. It never fails to bring a smile to my face when I cut into it and see them ripples. The most important thing with a cake of such beauty, though, is to make sure it tastes as good as it looks. Rather than keep the white cake batter plain or vanilla, I flavour mine with fresh orange zest or mashed banana. Orange and chocolate or banana and chocolate? Infinitely more interesting than just plain ol’ vanilla (sorry vanilla).

I hope you give this cake a try, it never disappoints.

P.S. I used an organic Cara Cara orange for this cake and it worked so wonderfully. The Cara Cara has a lovely coral flesh and a less intense citrus taste. It’s super sweet and I highly recommend it for baking and just to EAT. So scrummy.  I found them at Whole Foods.

Bonne Baking! xo

categories.title: Recipe
categories.description: This is where you add new recipes to the site.

ingredients:
For the cake: 

2 1/4 cups self raising flour
3/4 cup caster sugar or extra fine granulated sugar
2 1/4 tsp baking powder
3/4 tsp baking soda/bicarbonate of soda
1/3 tsp salt
1 1/2 tbsp apple cider vinegar
3/4 cup sunflower oil
4 1/2 tbsp brown rice syrup or golden syrup
1 cup warm milk + 1/4 cup 
1/4 cup cocoa
Zest of 1 orange 

For the icing:

8oz icing sugar
2oz butter
1 tbsp water
1 tbsp cocoa
1 tbsp milk
method:
Make your cake:

  1. Line your 8in cake tin with baking parchment and preheat your oven to 356F or 180C.
  2. Sieve the dry ingredients into a bowl in the following order: flour, sugar, salt, baking powder, baking soda.
  3. Add the syrup but avoid pouring it onto the baking powder and soda.
  4. Add the vinegar directly onto the baking powder and soda. The ingredients will react and you'll see lots of bubbles. This is exactly what you're looking for.
  5. In quick succession, add 1 cup milk and the oil.
  6. Mix the ingredients thoroughly until it is a smooth batter.
  7. In a second bowl, sieve 1/4 cup unsweetened cocoa.
  8. Pour just under half of the mix into the second bowl along with the remainder of the milk. Mix well until you have a smooth chocolate batter.
  9. Add the grated orange zest into the white batter.
  10. Now the fun part begins! Pour one large spoon/ladleful of white batter into the centre of the cake tin. Using another large spoon, place a spoonful of chocolate batter into the centre of the white batter. Keep on going, alternating spoons of each mix until you've used them both up.
  11. Place the tin in the oven and bake for 30 minutes.
  12. After 30 minutes, tear a piece of foil that would cover the cake tin, swiftly and gently open the oven door and cover the cake with the foil. This will allow it to cook without browning too much on top.
  13. Bake for a further 5 minutes. Pierce the the cake with a skewer. If it comes out clean it is cooked all the way through and you may remove it from the oven.
  14. Let the cake cool for at least an hour in the tin. It must be cool when you ice it. If you're in a hurry, let it cool for at least 30 minutes in the tin before removing it to accelerate cooling.

Make your icing:

Use a double boiler if you have one. If you don't, no problem. A double boiler basically consists of a bowl placed on top of a pan of simmering water. The bowl must not touch the water, but creates a seal with the bottom pan to trap the steam produced by the simmering water.
  1. Sieve icing/powdered sugar into a bowl that can be heated on a stove top.
  2. Add in the remaining ingredients.
  3. Place the bowl over a pan of simmering water, ensuring the bowl doesn't touch the water.
  4. Use a low-medium heat setting. If the pan gets too hot, the ingredients will become grainy rather than smooth.
  5. The chocolate icing will come together gradually as the butter melts. Stir occasionally to combine.
  6. Once you have a smooth chocolate icing, switch off the stove and remove the bowl from the heat. Allow the icing to cool for at least 10 minutes, stirring occasionally. You want the icing to thicken enough so that you can ice the cake with ease.
  7. Ice your cake! Use a knife without a serrated edge for a smoother finish.

posts.title: Vegan French Toast
posts.content:
This is a weekend breakfast staple. Sure, sometimes you wanna eat pancakes. Sometimes something savoury. But at other times you really just want some vegan sourdough french toast with stewed blueberries. AMIRITE?
I don’t use any refined sugar in this recipe either so there’s my vague nod to healthy and wholesome checked. Oh, and there’s some fruit to eat alongside it.

In all fairness, sourdough isn’t absolutely essential but I do think it adds to the overall texture and flavour of the toast. Regular sliced bread is squidgier, sourdough holds its own much better.

Serves 2.

categories.title: Recipe
categories.description: This is where you add new recipes to the site.

ingredients:
4 slices sourdough bread
1/2 mashed banana
1 tsp ground cinnamon
1/2 cup unsweetened vanilla almond milk
A pinch of ground nutmeg
A pinch of salt
1 tbsp all purpose flour

Coconut oil for frying
1 cup blueberries to serve.
method:
1. Whisk together the banana, almond milk, spices, salt and flour.
  2. Dip a slice of bread into the mixture. Flip it over to coat it fully.
  3. Heat a tsp of coconut oil on a griddle pan over a medium high heat.
  4. Once the pan is hot, place the slice of bread onto the melted coconut oil and cook until golden on both sides.
  5. Repeat with the remaining slices.
  6. For the stewed blueberries, simply cook the blueberries in a small non-stick saucepan over a low heat until they burst and release their juices. Toss the pan every few minutes to ensure the blueberries don't stick. For a runnier syrup, add one tablespoon of water to the saucepan and cook for approximately 5 minutes until the fruit juices come to a boil.
  7. Serve the toast with lashings of maple syrup, the blueberries and maybe some powdered sugar and extra cinnamon powder.

posts.title: Miniature Apple Pies
posts.content:
I’ve been wanting to make miniature hand pies for a while, for two reasons:

A) They are unashamedly adorable and inviting.

B) It’s just more practical to be able to make a few tiny pies rather than one big one that might not get finished. This way, you can make a few and bake them all if you like, or freeze a few raw ones for a future pie craving (is it just me who gets those?).

I went with a classic apple-cinnamon filling because it’s a real crowd pleaser. I would absolutely insist on using Granny Smith apples. The tartness that they contribute to the flavour profile is essential. The recipe for the pie crust dough is from the wonderful Joy the Baker.

*I didn’t have buttermilk so I improvised: 1/4 tbsp of lemon juice in 1/4 cup of milk. Leave for 10 mins before using.

categories.title: Recipe
categories.description: This is where you add new recipes to the site.

ingredients:
Yield: makes 9 hand pies 

For the pie crust:
1/2 cup or 1 stick butter, grated
1 1/4 cup all purpose flour
1/2 tsp salt
1 tbsp sugar
1/4 cup buttermilk*


For the filling: 
1/2 cup peeled and diced Granny Smith apple
1 tsp lemon juice
1/2 tsp ground cinnamon
1 tbsp brown sugar
1 tbsp all purpose flour
1/2 tbsp brown rice syrup
Fleur de sel (optional)


To glaze:
1 tbsp milk


To top: 
1 tbsp demerera sugar (optional)
method:
Make your pie crust dough:

  1. Measure out flour, salt and sugar into a bowl and combine. You may want to use the bowl of your stand mixer if you don't want to knead your pastry dough by hand.
  2. Add the grated butter and use your fingers to incorporate the butter into the flour. Keep going until the mixture resembles sand, with very few lumps.
  3. At this point, make a well in the mixture and add the buttermilk. Either with a fork or with your stand mixer, bring the dough together and knead for 3-4 minutes or until you have a smooth ball of dough. I did use a stand mixer to bring the ingredients together but I would still recommend you knead by hand on a floured surface for a couple of minutes.
  4. Flatten your dough into a thick disc, wrap in cling film and refrigerate for an hour.

Make your filling:

  1. Combine the filling ingredients in a bowl and mix well.

Make your pies:

  1. Preheat your oven to 400F and remove dough from the fridge.
  2. Line a baking tray with parchment paper.
  3. On a well-floured surface, roll out your dough to a 1/8in thickness.
  4. Using a 2.5in round cookie cutter, cut out 18 discs. Cut out as many as you can before re-rolling the cut offs.
  5. Lay out 9 discs on the baking tray.
  6. Place a tablespoon of your apple mixture in the middle of each disc.
  7. If using, sprinkle a few flakes of fleur de sel atop the pie filling.
  8. Cover the apple mixture with another disc.
  9. Pinch the pies closed with your fingertips and then seal with the tines of a fork. Be sure to seal them well!
  10. Using a sharp knife point or a skewer, poke 3-4 vent holes into the lid of each pie. This will ensure they don't burst while baking.
  11. Using a pastry brush, brush your pies with the milk. This will give them a lovely golden colour as they bake.
  12. If using, sprinkle the pies with the demerera sugar.
  13. Bake for 17 minutes or until golden brown and bubbling.
  14. Allow to cool for 10 minutes before serving.

posts.title: Baked Beet and Potato Chips
posts.content:
I’m an unapologetic grazer. Waiting 5 hours between meals ain’t for me. As a result, I try to make sure that what I’m snacking on is wholesome, unprocessed and ideally homemade. In all honesty, once I tried baking my own vegetable crisps/chips, store bought versions paled in comparison. These crisps/chips are super easy to make. Keeping it simple with just a pinch of salt and freshly ground black pepper means you can really taste the vegetables.

You will need a mandolin for this recipe.

categories.title: Recipe
categories.description: This is where you add new recipes to the site.

ingredients:
2 potatoes 
2 beetroots 
Olive Oil
Sea Salt
method:
1. Preheat your oven to 400F
  2. Wash and peel your vegetables
  3. Using the thin slicing setting on your mandolin, slice your vegetables into discs.
  4. Place the slices in a bowl and dress the vegetables with a glug of olive oil until they are very lightly coated.
  5. Evenly season the vegetables with the salt and black pepper.
  6. Place the vegetables on a non stick baking tray or a tray lined with baking parchment and lay them all out. They can be close to one another.
  7. Depending on their size they'll cook within 20-30 minutes. Keep an eye on them. Beets take longer than potatoes so after 20 minutes, rotate the tray and let them bake for 10-15 mins more.
  8. Once out of the oven, leave them on the tray to cool and crisp up.

posts.title: Chocolate Chunk Cookies
posts.content:
I’ve been trying to master the ultimate chocolate chip cookie for a while now. This has meant several trials and taste testing (research, of course) and I think I might just be getting somewhere. Some things I’ve learned along the way: always chill your dough before baking, always use good quality chocolate and always pair your chocolate with some sea salt. Those two guys are best friends, don’t keep ’em apart.

For me, these cookies are it.

They are beautifully soft in the middle.

They are loaded with seriously bittersweet chunks (NOT chips) of good quality chocolate.

They are studded with pecans that complement that chocolate perfectly.

They are flecked with sea salt that brings out the taste of chocolate like nothing else will.

They are egg free and aside from the sugar in the chocolate itself, refined sugar free.

You may think a yield of 6-7 cookies is a bit paltry. Well, friends, that’s because a larger yield has a habit of disappearing just as quickly as a small one in this house. So I had to halve it. No self control. Oh well. They’re worth every bite.

Yield: 6-7 medium sized cookies or 10 small.

categories.title: Recipe
categories.description: This is where you add new recipes to the site.

item:
5 tbsp butter
2 cups all purpose flour (you could substitute half for whole wheat flour)
1/3 tsp baking powder
1/3 tsp baking soda
1/4 cup brown rice syrup
1/4 cup + 1 tbsp light brown sugar
1/4 tsp salt
1 egg's worth of egg substitute (I used EnerG egg replacer)
2 oz dark chocolate, roughly chopped (at least 70% cocoa solids is recommended)
2 oz pecans, toasted and chopped
 
A pinch of sea salt flakes/fleur de sel for sprinkling
ingredients:
5 tbsp butter
2 1/4 cups all purpose flour
1/3 tsp baking powder
1/3 tsp baking soda
1/4 cup brown rice syrup
1/4 cup + 1 tbsp light brown sugar
1/4 tsp salt 
1 egg's worth of egg substitute (I used EnerG egg replacer)
60g dark chocolate, roughly chopped (I highly recommend 85% cocoa solids, but 70% would work too)
60g pecans, toasted and chopped

A pinch of sea salt flakes/fleur de sel for sprinkling.
method:
1. Melt the butter.
  2. Measure out the dry ingredients into a bowl.
  3. Pour in the melted butter and mix through.
  4. Add the egg substitute and your mix should begin to form a dough. (If your mix is too wet, add a tablespoon of flour. Do so again if necessary.)
  5. Fold in the chocolate and pecans.
  6. Form your dough into cookies, making sure they're evenly sized.
  7. Refrigerate the dough for a minimum of 2 hours in an airtight container, ensuring they don't stick to one another. If you have the time, overnight refrigeration is ideal.
  8. When you're ready to bake, preheat your oven to 400F.
  9. Remove the dough from the fridge for 10 minutes before baking
  10. Place the dough on a tray, leaving 2 inches between each one.
  11. Sprinkle with the salt flakes.
  12. Bake for 8-10 mins (8 for smaller cookies and 10 for medium).
  13. Let the cookies cool slightly on the baking tray before transferring them to a wire rack.
  14. Gobble. Incidentally, the raw dough also freezes wonderfully, so you may want to double (or treble) the recipe and save a few for a rainy day.
